          <div class="row-fluid"><div class="region region-sidebar-first clearfix">
  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Graduate Program</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-stanford_jsa_layouts-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">
  <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-992"><a href="/graduate-program/graduate-program-overview">Overview</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-965"><a href="/graduate-program/applying-graduate-program">Applying to the Graduate Program</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-960"><a href="/graduate-program/master-arts">Master of Arts</a></li>
<li class="expanded active-trail menu-mlid-963 dropdown-submenu"><a href="/graduate-program/phd" class="active-trail dropdown-toggle" data-toggle="dropdown" data-target="#">Ph.D.</a><ul class="dropdown-menu"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-979"><a href="/graduate-program/phd/applying-phd">Applying to the Ph.D.</a></li>
<li class="expanded active-trail menu-mlid-996 dropdown-submenu"><a href="/graduate-program/phd/phd-requirements" class="active-trail dropdown-toggle" data-toggle="dropdown" data-target="#">Requirements</a><ul class="dropdown-menu"><li class="first leaf active-trail active menu-mlid-1035"><a href="/graduate-program/phd/requirements/phd-chinese" class="active-trail active">Ph.D. in Chinese</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1034"><a href="/graduate-program/phd/requirements/phd-chinese-archaeology-subplan">Ph.D., Chinese Archaeology Subplan</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1033"><a href="/graduate-program/phd/requirements/literature-track">Ph.D. in Japanese, Literature Track</a></li>
<li class="last leaf menu-mlid-1031"><a href="/graduate-program/phd/requirements/linguistics-track">Ph.D. in Japanese, Linguistics Track</a></li>

</ul></li>

        <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Ph.D. in Chinese </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-281" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/graduate-program/phd/requirements/phd-chinese" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Ph.D. in Chinese" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary">The Ph.D. program in Chinese is designed to prepare students for a doctoral degree in Chinese literature, philosophy, or linguistics.</p>
<p>Applicants must have a minimum of three years of Chinese language study at Stanford or the equivalent to be considered for admission. Ph.D. students will complete the M.A. (as described in the M.A. requirements section on this website) on the way to advancing to Ph.D. candidacy. The majority of required course work for Ph.D. students demands the ability to read primary and secondary materials in Chinese. Advanced standing may be considered for students entering the Ph.D. program who have already completed an M.A. in Chinese literature or linguistics elsewhere only in cases when the level of prior course work and research is deemed equivalent to departmental requirements for the Ph.D. All courses must be taken for a letter grade.</p>
<p>For a Ph.D. in Chinese, a candidate must fulfill the following requirements:</p>
<ol><li>Complete the department's requirements for the M.A. in Chinese and two of three advanced classical Chinese Courses: CHINLIT 221, Advanced Classical Chinese: Philosophical Texts; CHINLIT 222, Advanced Classical Chinese: Historical Narration; or CHINLIT 223, Advanced Classical Chinese: Literary Essays. All incoming Ph.D. students must take a placement test in classical Chinese held during Orientation Week of fall quarter. Those who fail to place into the advanced level must take Beginning Classical Chinese.</li>
	<li>Demonstrate proficiency in at least one supporting language, to be chosen in consultation with the primary adviser according to the candidate's specific research goals. Reading proficiency must be certified through a written examination or an appropriate amount of coursework, to be determined on a case-by-case basis. When deemed necessary by the student's adviser(s), working knowledge of a third language may also be required.</li>
	<li>Students in Chinese literature must take at least one Chinese linguistics course, and linguistics students must take at least one literature course.  One linguistics course is CHINA 291:  Structure of Modern Chinese.</li>
	<li>Complete two relevant seminars at the 300 level. These seminars must be in different subjects.</li>
	<li>Pass a set of three comprehensive written examinations, one of which tests the candidate's methodological competence in the relevant discipline. The remaining two fields are chosen, with the approval of the graduate adviser in consultation with the student's individual adviser, from the following: archaeolology, anthropology, art, Chinese literature, history, Japanese literature, linguistics, philosophy, and religion. With the adviser's approval, a Ph.D. minor in a supporting field may be deemed equivalent to the completion of one of these three examinations.</li>
	<li>Demonstrate pedagogical proficiency by serving as a teaching assistant for a minimum of one quarter, and taking DLCL 301, The Learning and Teaching of Second Languages.</li>
	<li>Pass the University Oral Examination — General regulations governing the oral examination are found in the "Graduate Degrees" section of the University Bulletin. The candidate is examined on questions related to the dissertation after acceptable parts of it have been completed in draft form.</li>
	<li>Submit a dissertation demonstrating ability to undertake original research based on primary materials in Chinese.</li>
</ol></div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> East Asian Studies, China Subplan </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-434" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies-china-subplan" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="East Asian Studies, China Subplan" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><h2><span>Requirements for the Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, China Subplan</span></h2>
<p>The Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, China Subplan, offers students the ability to study East Asia with a special focus on Chinese culture and language. The Bachelor of Arts The Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, China Subplan, replaced the department's Bachelor of Arts in Chinese. Students currently pursuing the Bachelor of Arts in Chinese may choose to continue his or her plan of study, or opt to complete the Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, China Subplan requirement instead. Note: Once students drop the Bachelor of Arts in Chinese on Axess, they cannot re-enroll/declare under the Bachelor of Arts in Chinese again. Consult Prof. Yiqun Zhou, EALC’s Director of Undergraduate Studies, or Ai Tran, EALC’s student services officer, for more clarification.</p>
<p>The following requirements are are in addition to the University’s basic requirements for the bachelor’s degree. Letter grades are mandatory for required courses.</p>
<p>Courses taken to complete the major requirements as well as their prerequisites must be completed with a grade point average (GPA) of 2.0 or better.</p>
<ol><li>Gateway Courses: Students must take two gateway courses appropriate to the East Asian Studies, China Subplan. Courses can be from the “East Asian Gateway Course Cluster” and/or the “Gateway Course Cluster for the China Subplan." At least one of the two gateway courses chosen must be taught by a member in the EALC department. <a href="https://stanford.box.com/v/EALCGatewayCourses" rel="nofollow">List of Approved Gateway Courses.</a></li>
	<li>Proficiency of the modern Chinese language, at the third year level: Students take a minimum of 3 years of modern Chinese language courses. Students should take a language assessment test offered at the Language Center to determine language proficiency before signing up for classes. </li>
	<li>Beginning classical Chinese: Students must take at least one classical Chinese course.
		<ol><li>CHINA 105: Beginning Classical Chinese, First Quarter</li>
			<li>CHINA 106: Beginning Classical Chinese, Second Quarter</li>
			<li>CHINA 107: Beginning Classical Chinese, Third Quarter</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li>Additional courses: Students must take additional content courses to fulfill the requirement. The following courses selected should be discussed with the Director of Undergraduate Studies for approval.
		<ol><li>Three CHINA courses at the 100 level with one in each of the following areas: pre-modern China, modern China, and Chinese linguistics.</li>
			<li>Four other content courses, as approved by the undergraduate faculty adviser. One of these should be a History course offered by the Department of History.</li>
			<li>All students take <em><strong>CHINA 111: Literature in 20-th Century China</strong></em> as part of the Writing in the Major (WIM) requirement.</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li><strong>Capstone requirement:</strong> Students enroll in <em><strong>EALC 198: Senior Colloquium</strong></em> winter quarter of the senior year with other seniors to complete the Senior Capstone Essay or Honors Thesis. A capstone essay is approximately 7,500 words, and the honors thesis approximately 15,000.</li>
</ol><p>For questions or inquiries regarding the major, please contact our department student services officer, Ai Tran (<a href="mailto:aitran@stanford.edu?subject=Chinese%20Major%20Requirements" rel="nofollow">aitran@stanford.edu</a>).</p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-435" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies-japan-subplan" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><h2><span>Requirements for the Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan</span></h2>
<p>The Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan, offers students the ability to study East Asia with a special focus on Japanese culture and language. The Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan, replaced the department's Bachelor of Arts in Japanese. Students currently pursuing the Bachelor of Arts in Japanese may choose to continue his or her plan of study, or opt to complete the Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan requirement instead. Note: Once students drop the Bachelor of Arts in Japanese on Axess, he or she cannot re-enroll/declare under the Bachelor of Arts in Japanese again. Consult Prof. Yiqun Zhou, Director of Undergraduate Studies, or Ai Tran, EALC’s student services officer, for more clarification.</p>
<p>The following requirements are are in addition to the University’s basic requirements for the bachelor’s degree. Letter grades are mandatory for required courses.</p>
<p>Courses taken to complete the major requirements as well as their prerequisites must be completed with a grade point average (GPA) of 2.0 or better.</p>
<ol><li>Gateway courses: Students must take two gateway courses appropriate to the East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan. Courses can be from the “East Asian Gateway Course Cluster” and/or the “Gateway Course Cluster for the Japan Subplan." At least one of the two gateway courses chosen must be taught by a member in the EALC department. <a href="https://stanford.box.com/v/EALCGatewayCourses" rel="nofollow">List of Approved Gateway Courses.</a></li>
	<li>Proficiency of the modern Japanese language, at the third year level: Students take a minimum of 3 years of modern Japanese language courses. Students should take a language assessment test offered at the Language Center to determine language proficiency before signing up for classes.</li>
	<li>Additional courses: Students must take additional content courses to fulfill the requirement. The following courses selected should be discussed with the Director of Undergraduate Studies for approval.
		<ol><li>Three JAPAN courses at the 100-level with one in each of the following areas: pre-modern Japan, modern Japan, and Japanese linguistics.</li>
			<li>Four other content courses dealin with Japan primarily at the 100-level.</li>
			<li>Amongst the list of "Additional courses," all students must take <em><strong>JAPAN 138: Introduction to Modern Japanese Literature and Culture</strong></em>, our Writing in the Major (WIM) course</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li><strong>Capstone Requirement:</strong> Students enroll in <em><strong>EALC 198: Senior Colloquium</strong></em> winter quarter of the senior year with other seniors to complete the Senior Capstone Essay or Honors Thesis. A capstone essay is approximately 7,500 words, and the honors thesis approximately 15,000.</li>
</ol><p>For questions or inquiries regarding the major, please contact our department student services officer, Ai Tran (<a href="mailto:aitran@stanford.edu?subject=Chinese%20Major%20Requirements" rel="nofollow">aitran@stanford.edu</a>).</p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>
                                                                                                                      </div>
          <!-- /#content-wrap -->
        </div>
        <!-- /#content -->
              </div>
                </div>
  </div>
  <!-- /#main, /#main-wrapper -->
    <div id="push"></div>
  <!-- /#push -->

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-436" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies-korea-subplan" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><h2><span>Requirements for the Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan</span></h2>
<p>The Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan, offers students the ability to study East Asia with a special focus on Korean culture and language. The following requirements are in addtion to the University's basic requiremenets for the bachelor's degree. Students must take all courses for a letter grade, and the courses as well as their prerequisites must be completed with a grade point average (GPA) of 2.0 or better.</p>
<ol><li>Gateway courses: Students must take two gateway courses appropriate to the East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan. Courses can be from the “East Asian Gateway Course Cluster” and/or the “Gateway Course Cluster for the Korea Subplan." At least one of the two gateway courses chosen must be taught by a member in the EALC department. <a href="https://stanford.box.com/v/EALCGatewayCourses" rel="nofollow">List of Approved Gateway Courses.</a></li>
	<li>Proficiency of the modern Korean language, at the third year level: Students take a minimum of 3 years of modern Korean language courses. Students should take a language assessment test offered at the Language Center to determine language proficiency before signing up for classes.</li>
	<li>Additional courses: Students must take additional content courses to fulfill the requirement. The following courses selected should be discussed with the Director of Undergraduate Studies for approval.
		<ol><li>Take 6 KOREA courses at the 100-level, a minimum of two 100-level courses must be offered by the department.</li>
			<li>Amongst the list of "Additional courses," all students must take <em><strong>KOREA 120: Narratives of Modern and Contemporary Korea</strong></em>, our Writing in the Major (WIM) course</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li><strong>Capstone Requirement:</strong> Students enroll in <em><strong>EALC 198: Senior Colloquium</strong></em> winter quarter of the senior year with other seniors to complete the Senior Capstone Essay or Honors Thesis. A capstone essay is approximately 7,500 words, and the honors thesis approximately 15,000.</li>
</ol><p>For questions or inquiries regarding the major, please contact our department student services officer, Ai Tran (<a href="mailto:aitran@stanford.edu?subject=Chinese%20Major%20Requirements" rel="nofollow">aitran@stanford.edu</a>).</p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->

<div id="block-bean-jumpstart-footer-social-media-0" class="clearfix block block-bean span2">     <h2>Connect</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="entity entity-bean bean-stanford-social-media-connect clearfix" about="/block/jumpstart-footer-social-media--0" typeof="">

  <div class="content">

<meta name="description" content="Most courses in the Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures are taught by tenure-line faculty, and are small in size, so that students receive individual attention. The department’s courses have the subject codes CHINGEN, CHINLIT, JAPANGEN, JAPANLIT, KORGEN, and KORLIT. General courses are open to all undergraduates and graduate students, are taught in English, and do not require knowledge of an East Asian language. CHINESE CONTENT COURSES 15-16" />

http://givingtostanford.stanford.edu
1) In the scroll down menus provided, please direct your gift to School of Humanities and Sciences.
2) In the next step, select Dept or Program and specify Asian Languages in the special instruction/designation field below.
You can also mail your contribution to the EALC office. Checks should be made payable to “Stanford University.”
For assistance or more information, please contact:
Connie Chin, Manager, EALC

  <div id="main" class="clearfix main" role="main">

            <div id="main-content" class="row main-content">

          <div class="row-fluid"><div class="region region-sidebar-first clearfix">
  <div id="block-bean-jumpstart-featured-course" class="clearfix block block-bean well">     <h2>JAPAN 288: The Japanese Tea Ceremony</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="entity entity-bean bean-stanford-postcard clearfix" about="/block/jumpstart-featured-course" typeof="">

  <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard"><div class="field-collection-container clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-info field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-4-col-header field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/5" typeof="">
  <div class="content">
    <div class="border-simple-nowidth border-shadow"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/4-col-header/public/photo-1460050009045-c8b8e86106a8_0.jpg?itok=UJcteKdt" width="370" height="140" alt="Japanese Teapot" /></div></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-field-s-postcard-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span>"When I first saw that [JAPAN 288], “The Japanese Tea Ceremony: The History, Aesthetics and Politics Behind a National Pastime,” was a course offered during Stanford’s spring quarter I was floored. I couldn’t believe that such a nuanced interest of mine was woven into the fabric of Stanford’s academic net. Needless to say, I was quick to sign up, early to the first day and sleepless the nights before class. </span><span>... </span><span>What started out as an intellectual interest has become a philosophical meditation on how to be in the world, all of which is the result of this exceptional class. Learning from experiences such as this one, in which practical application or future security become less of a central focus, are truly precious. They move the mindset of education away from financial success and push instead for a greater depth of character and understanding of self. When the time next comes to enroll in classes I beg you all to discover the </span>hidden wonders that Stanford and learning have to offer you<span>. To put aside your inclination towards the comfort of pragmatism and experiment instead with your curious and perhaps less acknowledged side."</span></p>
<p><span>-- Hannah Broderick, Stanford Undergraduate</span></p>
</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-postcard-link field-type-link-field field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://www.stanforddaily.com/2016/04/26/mediations-on-tea/" class="more-link">Continue reading...</a></div><div class="field-item odd"><a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/search?view=catalog&amp;filter-coursestatus-Active=on&amp;page=0&amp;catalog=&amp;academicYear=&amp;q=japangen%20287a&amp;collapse=" class="more-link">JAPANGEN 287A/ARTHIST 287A: The Japanese Tea Ceremony</a></div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
 </div>
</div>
</div>
 <!-- /.region -->
</div>
        </div>
        <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Courses </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-178" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/courses" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Courses" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-image group_s_postcard_image"><div class="field-collection-container clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-info field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-large-scaled field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/290" typeof="">
  <div class="content">
    <div class="border-simple-nowidth border-shadow"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-scaled/public/photo-1444730558009-b7f0368e1264.jpg?itok=kqRAcvAG" width="270" height="152" alt="" /></div></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary">Most courses in the Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures are taught by tenure-line faculty, and are small in size, so that students receive individual attention.</p>
<p>The department’s courses have the subject codes CHINGEN, CHINLIT, JAPANGEN, JAPANLIT, KORGEN, and KORLIT. General courses are open to all undergraduates and graduate students, are taught in English, and do not require knowledge of an East Asian language.</p>
<p>CHINESE CONTENT COURSES 15-16</p>
<ul><li><a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/search?view=catalog&amp;academicYear=&amp;page=0&amp;q=CHINA&amp;filter-departmentcode-CHINA=on&amp;filter-coursestatus-Active=on&amp;filter-term-Spring=on">click here for courses with CHINA subject code</a></li>
</ul><p>JAPANESE CONTENT COURSES 15-16</p>
<ul><li><a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/search?view=catalog&amp;academicYear=&amp;page=0&amp;q=JAPAN&amp;filter-departmentcode-JAPAN=on&amp;filter-coursestatus-Active=on&amp;filter-term-Spring=on">click here for courses with JAPAN subject code</a></li>
</ul><p>KOREAN CONTENT COURSES 15-16</p>
<ul><li><a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/search?view=catalog&amp;academicYear=&amp;page=0&amp;q=KOREA&amp;filter-departmentcode-KOREA=on&amp;filter-coursestatus-Active=on&amp;filter-term-Spring=on">click here for courses with KOREA subject code</a></li>
</ul><p>Please check back in August for an updated list of our course offerings for AY 2016-17. For more information about our courses, please contact our Student Services Officer, Ai Tran (<a href="mailto:aitran@stanford.edu?subject=Question%20about%20EALC%20Course%20Offering" rel="nofollow">aitran@stanford.edu</a>).</p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>
                                                                                                                      </div>

<meta name="description" content="The Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures offers programs for students who wish to engage with the cultures of China, Japan, and Korea as articulated in language, linguistics, literature, film, cultural studies, and visual arts. Students emerge with a sophisticated understanding of culture as a dynamic process embodied in language and other representational media, especially the verbal and visual forms that are central to humanistic study." />

http://givingtostanford.stanford.edu
1) In the scroll down menus provided, please direct your gift to School of Humanities and Sciences.
2) In the next step, select Dept or Program and specify Asian Languages in the special instruction/designation field below.
You can also mail your contribution to the EALC office. Checks should be made payable to “Stanford University.”
For assistance or more information, please contact:
Connie Chin, Manager, EALC
521 Memorial Way
Stanford, CA 94305
Email: csquare@stanford.edu">Giving</a></li>
</ul></li>

  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Graduate Program</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-stanford_jsa_layouts-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">
  <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf active-trail active menu-mlid-992"><a href="/graduate-program/graduate-program-overview" class="active-trail active">Overview</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-965"><a href="/graduate-program/applying-graduate-program">Applying to the Graduate Program</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-960"><a href="/graduate-program/master-arts">Master of Arts</a></li>

</ul></div>

<div id="block-bean-jumpstart-graduate-in-the-spotli" class="clearfix block block-bean well">     <h2>Why am I glad to be a part of EALC?</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="entity entity-bean bean-stanford-postcard clearfix" about="/block/jumpstart-graduate-in-the-spotli" typeof="">

  <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-field-s-postcard-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p class="float-left"><img alt="Image of PhD Grad Student, Kevin Singleton" src="https://ealc.stanford.edu/s3/files/styles/sm-square/public/singletonkevin-phd_1.jpg?itok=VOCR7oN6" /></p>
<p>“Why am I glad to be a part of the EALC? That’s easy enough. The freedom (and resources) to pursue my own academic interests, professors equally attentive to the pursuit of knowledge and the practical exigencies of professional development, a supportive community of graduate students who continue to teach me new things on a daily basis, and opportunities to engage with contemporary authors and scholars hailing from all over the globe. If you have never thought that, say, Japanese linked verse from the 15th century or the popular literature of the early Showa Period could be exciting, I would ask you first to visit our doors.”</p>
<p>-- Kevin Singleton, Japanese PhD Candidate</p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
 </div>
</div>
</div>
 <!-- /.region -->
</div>
        </div>
        <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Graduate Program Overview </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-150" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/graduate-program/graduate-program-overview" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Graduate Program Overview" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary">The Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures offers programs for students who wish to engage with the cultures of China, Japan, and Korea as articulated in language, linguistics, literature, film, cultural studies, and visual arts. Students emerge with a sophisticated understanding of culture as a dynamic process embodied in language and other representational media, especially the verbal and visual forms that are central to humanistic study.</p>
<p>Our department currently offer the following programs:</p>
<ul><li>Master of Arts in Chinese</li>
<li>Master of Arts in Japanese</li>
<li>Doctor of Philosophy in Chinese</li>
<li>Doctor of Philosophy in Chinese, Archaeology Subplan</li>
<li>Doctor of Philosophy in Japanese</li>
<li>Doctor of Philosophy in Japanese, Linguistics Track</li>
</ul><p>All students contemplating application for admission to graduate study must have a creditable undergraduate record. The applicant need not have majored in Chinese or Japanese as an undergraduate, but must have had the equivalent of least three years of training in the language in which he or she intends to specialize, and must also demonstrate a command of English adequate for the pursuit of graduate study. Applicants should not wish merely to acquire or improve language skills, but to pursue study in one of the following fields: Chinese History (pre-modern), Chinese linguistics, Chinese literature, Chinese Philosophy, Japanese cultural history, Japanese literature and Japanese linguistics.</p>
<p>For more information, please explore other pages to learn more about our graduate programs. Please contact our Student Services Officer, <a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/people/staff">Ai Tran</a> (<a href="mailto:aitran@stanford.edu?subject=Question%20about%20East%20Asian%20Languages%20%26%20Cultures'%20Graduate%20Program">aitran@stanford.edu</a>).</p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Applying to the Graduate Program </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-113" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/graduate-program/applying-graduate-program" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Applying to the Graduate Program" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-image group_s_postcard_image"><div class="field-collection-container clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-info field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-large-scaled field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/299" typeof="">
  <div class="content">
    <div class="border-simple-nowidth border-shadow"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-scaled/public/changdeokgung-786592.jpg?itok=3s29xFC2" width="270" height="180" alt="" /></div></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary"><span>The Application Deadline for the 2017-18 has passed. The 2018-19 application will be available in early September 2017; please check back in September for more application details. The deadline submit your application for 2018-19 will be on <strong>Tuesday, December 5, 2017</strong>, 11:59 pm PST.  </span></p>
<p>Graduate study is offered in more than 60 departments and programs. Since you may submit only one application per academic year, it is essential that you carefully review the available programs. We recommend students review all available programs, before applying. During your application process you will be able to designate whether you would potentially like your application to be referred to a different department, although this does no guarantee that the other department will offer you candidacy.</p>
<h3>Stanford University Eligibility Requirements</h3>
<p><span>To be eligible for admission to graduate programs at Stanford, applicants must meet </span>one<span> of the following conditions:</span></p>
<ul><li>Applicants must hold, or expect to hold before enrollment at Stanford, a bachelor’s degree from a U.S. college or university accredited by a regional accrediting association.</li>
	<li>Applicants from institutions outside the U.S. must hold the equivalent of a U.S. bachelor’s degree from a college or university of recognized standing. See minimum level of study required of International applicants.</li>
</ul><h4>English Language Proficiency</h4>
<p><span>Adequate command of spoken and written English is required for admission. Evidence of adequate English proficiency must be submitted before enrollment is approved by Graduate Admissions.</span></p>
<p>TOEFL (Test of English as a Foreign Language) scores are required of all applicants whose first language is not English.</p>
<p>International students enrolled at Stanford must be able to read English with ease, understand rapid idiomatic English as used in lectures and group discussions, and express thoughts quickly and clearly in spoken and written English. Admission is offered only to students who are fully prepared in English or who have advanced intermediate proficiency in English that could be raised to the required level by enrollment in a summer intensive English program.</p>
<p>Stanford University offers a six-week Intensive English and Academic Orientation Program in the summer for students who plan to begin graduate study in the autumn quarter.</p>
<h4>Stanford English Placement Test</h4>
<p>The English for Foreign Students Office administers an English placement test at the beginning of each quarter. This test may be a required condition of admission for students whose native language is not English.</p>
<p>Standard protocol for the test involve:</p>
<ul><li>The test assesses the ability to understand, speak, and write American English with particular emphasis on active speaking and writing.</li>
	<li>Results are evaluated in terms of the students’ intended academic programs at Stanford and the University’s requirements for that program.</li>
	<li>The results of the test determine whether students will be required to take courses in English in addition to their academic courses.</li>
	<li>Completion of a degree program may be lengthened if the English courses are required.</li>
	<li>Students who hold teaching assistantships or who are enrolled in a PhD program that has a teaching requirement will be evaluated in a separate test for oral communication in English.</li>
	<li>A special English course for teaching assistantships is available for students who are found to need additional language training before beginning their teaching assignments.</li>
</ul><p> </p>
<p class="summary"><span>Please check the appropriate pages below to see admissions requirements:</span></p>
<p><a class="btn" href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/master-arts/applying-ma" rel="nofollow">Masters of Arts Requirements</a></p>
<p><a class="btn" href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/phd/applying-phd" rel="nofollow">Ph.D. Requirements</a></p>
<p> </p>
<h4>Stanford Knight-Hennessy Scholars Program</h4>
<p>The Knight-Henessy Scholars program awards full funding to pursue a graduate education at Stanford to students from all disciplines, with additional opportunities for leadership training and collaboration across fields. </p>
<p><a href="https://knight-hennessy.stanford.edu/admission/apply-now">Apply to Knight-Hennessy Scholars</a> by September 27, 2017, and to the degree program of your choice by November 15, 2017.</p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>

  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Graduate Program</h2>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> M.A. Timeline </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-142" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/graduate-program/deadlines" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="M.A. Timeline" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-image group_s_postcard_image"><div class="field-collection-container clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-info field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-large-scaled field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/289" typeof="">
  <div class="content">
    <div class="border-simple-nowidth border-shadow"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-scaled/public/85.1086.512.dsc_0107_0.jpg?itok=CdyZ65Ku" width="270" height="180" alt="" /></div></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p><span>Once admitted to the M.A. program, M.A. candidates must accept or decline our offer before the start of the Autumn quarter that he or she is admitted to. 2016-17 Admitted M.A. students should visit the Grad Admissions: Admitted Students webpage and complete all requirements necessary. </span><span>Students who accept an offer of admission will be notiﬁed later by e-mail from Graduate Admissions, Office of the University Registrar, about any additional requirements to be fulﬁlled. The requirements will also appear in the student’s <a href="https://axess.sahr.stanford.edu/">Axess</a> </span><span>account To Do list. Students who are not U.S. citizens or U.S. registered permanent residents need to<a href="https://gradadmissions.stanford.edu/admitted-students/entering-stanford/international-students/i-20-ds-2019-and-transfer-requests"> fill out and submit either the I-20 Request for Student F-1 Visa or the DS-2019 Request for J-1 Exchange Visitors, and possibly Transfer in (SEVIS Record) to Stanford University.</a></span></p>
<p><span>If there are any follw-up questions, students should direct questions either to Grad Admissions (</span><a href="mailto:gradadmissions@stanford.edu" rel="nofollow">gradadmissions@stanford.edu</a><span>), or East Asian Languages &amp; Culture's Student Services Officer, Ai Tran (</span><a href="mailto:aitran@stanford.edu" rel="nofollow">aitran@stanford.edu</a><span>). </span></p>
<h4>First Year: Autumn Quarter</h4>
<ul><li>Attend the department orientation for grad students. An email will be sent out closer to the date notifying grad students of the time and meeting place. At the orientation, the Director of Graduate Studies, Professor <a href="https://profiles.stanford.edu/ban-wang">Ban Wang</a>, will go over the EALC Graduate Handbook, department expectations and requirements for M.A. students. You will also be asked to complete the following forms, required by the department:
		<ul><li>EALC Emergency Contact Information</li>
			<li>EALC Information Consent Waiver Form</li>
		</ul></li>
	<li><strong><em>For International Students:</em></strong> i<span>f you are an international student whose native language is not English, you may be required to take the English Placement Test upon arrival. Students who accept an offer of admission and who Graduate Admissions requires to take the test will find that item on their To Do list in their Axess account. <a href="http://web.stanford.edu/group/efs/platest.html">For more information, please click here.</a></span></li>
	<li><span>Students may also attend the <a href="https://glo.stanford.edu/ngso">New Graduate Student Orientation</a>, hosted by the Graduate Life Office. Every year, the Graduate Life Office works with student volunteers to coordinate the New Graduate Student Orientation, or NGSO. In hopes to orient Stanford's new graduate students to the campus and ease their transitions here, it occurs the week prior to the start of classes. The programs are open to all incoming graduate students, both new and transfer students. <strong><em>For International Students: </em></strong>whether you </span><span>arrive before orientation or during orientation, be sure to visit <a href="https://bechtel.stanford.edu/">Stanford's Bechtel International Center</a> (I-Center) website for full details of the <a href="https://bechtel.stanford.edu/coming-stanford/new-student-information/international-student-orientation">Graduate International Student Orientation.</a></span></li>
</ul><h4>First Year: Spring Quarter</h4>
<ul><li>At the beginning of the spring quarter, all graduate students must complete the Department's Annual Review Progress Report. Department faculty will use the information to evaluate student progress, and provide students with feedback.</li>
	<li>Towards the end of the spring quarter, students should at this point identify potential department faculty members who could serve as their thesis adviser(s). Once the faculty member has agreed to be their thesis adviser, students should work with the professor for the remainder of their time at Stanford to complete their thesis, while <span>taking courses to complete the 45-unit minimum requirement and requirements specific to Chinese or Japanese M.A. program.</span></li>
</ul><h4>Second Year: Autumn Quarter</h4>
<ul><li>If the M.A. student has not done so already, he or she should find a faculty member who will be his or her thesis adviser, and begin working with the thesis adviser to complete the M.A. thesis, while taking courses to complete the 45-unit minimum requirement and requirements specific to Chinese or Japanese M.A. program.</li>
</ul><h4>Second Year: Spring Quarter</h4>
<ul><li>At the beginning of the spring quarter, all graduate students must complete the <span>Department's Annual Review Progress Report. Department faculty will use the information to evaluate student progress, and provide students with feedback.</span></li>
	<li>Except for unexpected circumstances, second-year M.A. students should be graduating by spring quarter. Students must:
		<ul><li>Apply to Graduate by the spring quarter deadline. For dates specific to your year, please check the <a href="https://registrar.stanford.edu/resources-and-help/stanford-academic-calendar">Stanford Academic Calendar.</a></li>
			<li>Submit the M.A. thesis by the spring quarter deadline. <span>For dates specific to your year, and instruction on submitting your thesis, <a href="https://registrar.stanford.edu/students/dissertation-and-thesis-submission">click here.</a></span></li>
			<li><span>Complete the Department's Diploma Ceremony RSVP, which will be emailed to the graduate student mailing list.</span></li>
			<li>For more information on graduation and commencement, please <a href="https://registrar.stanford.edu/students/graduation/important-graduation-dates-spring">visit the Office of the Registrar's website.</a></li>
		</ul></li>
	<li>Second-year students who will <strong>not</strong> be graduating in the spring, please make an appointment to talk to the Student Services Officer no later than two weeks <em><strong>before</strong></em> the Apply to Graduate deadline for spring quarter.</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

<meta name="description" content="Similar to the East Asian Studies Workshop, the East Asian Linguistics Workshop is sponsored by the Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures. The workshop&#039;s purpose is to promote intra- and inter-departmental communication among faculty, graduate students, and visiting scholars who share research and teaching interest in East Asia in the Stanford Community. Primarily, the East Asian Linguistics workshop focuses on Asian Linguistics." />

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> East Asian Linguistics Workshop </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-378" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/graduate-program/east-asian-linguistics-workshop" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="East Asian Linguistics Workshop" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-image group_s_postcard_image"><div class="field-collection-container clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-info field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-large-scaled field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/297" typeof="">
  <div class="content">
    <div class="border-simple-nowidth border-shadow"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-scaled/public/maxresdefault.jpg?itok=yhcW1hjN" width="270" height="152" alt="" /></div></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>Similar to the East Asian Studies Workshop, the East Asian Linguistics Workshop is sponsored by the Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures. The workshop's purpose is to promote intra- and inter-departmental communication among faculty, graduate students, and visiting scholars who share research and teaching interest in East Asia in the Stanford Community. Primarily, the East Asian Linguistics workshop focuses on Asian Linguistics. These workshops take place once a month; upcoming workshops can be found on our <a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/news-events/upcoming-events">Events</a> website, beginning with <strong>"East Asian Linguistics Workshop: ..." </strong></p>
<p>If you are interested in attending our workshops, please contact our 2016-2017 graduate student coordinator, Paul Ganir (<a href="mailto:pganir@stanford.edu" rel="nofollow">pganir@stanford.edu</a>).</p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

<div id="block-bean-jumpstart-footer-contact-block" class="clearfix block block-bean span2">     <h2>Contact Us</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="entity entity-bean bean-stanford-contact clearfix" about="/block/jumpstart-footer-contact-block" typeof="">

  <div class="content">

<meta name="description" content="Sponsored by the Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures, the East Asian Studies Workshop aims at promoting intra- and inter-departmental communication among faculty, graduate students, and visiting scholars who share research and teaching interests in East Asia in the Stanford community.  In particular, it is intended to foster stronger ties between EALC faculty and graduate students across the China-Japan-Korea divide as well as greater cross-disciplinary exchange among East Asian Studies scholars across the" />

  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Graduate Program</h2>

        <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> East Asian Studies Workshop </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-158" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/graduate-program/east-asian-studies-workshop" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="East Asian Studies Workshop" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-image group_s_postcard_image"><div class="field-collection-container clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-info field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-large-scaled field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/296" typeof="">
  <div class="content">
    <div class="border-simple-nowidth border-shadow"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-scaled/public/photo-1435527173128-983b87201f4d_0.jpg?itok=bnjQE00W" width="270" height="181" alt="" /></div></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p><span>Sponsored by the Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures, the East Asian Studies Workshop aims at promoting intra- and inter-departmental communication among faculty, graduate students, and visiting scholars who share research and teaching interests in East Asia in the Stanford community.  In particular, it is intended to foster stronger ties between EALC faculty and graduate students across the China-Japan-Korea divide as well as greater cross-disciplinary exchange among East Asian Studies scholars across the humanities and social science disciplines, including literature, linguistics, history, art history, religion, philosophy, anthropology, sociology, and political science.  It is also intended to enhance graduate student professionalization.  The workshop meets once a month during the academic year and engage in a variety of activities determined by its participants. </span></p>
<p><span>Our workshops can be found on our </span><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/news-events/upcoming-events">Events</a><span> webpage, beginning with<strong> "East Asian Studies Workshop: ..." </strong></span><span>If you might not be able to attend this session but have suggestions you would like to make for future workshop activities, please feel free to email your ideas to our 2015-16 graduate student coordinators, Likun Yang and Timothy Young (<a href="mailto:stanfordeasw@gmail.com?subject=Stanford%20East%20Asian%20Studies%20Workshop" rel="nofollow">stanfordeasw@gmail.com</a>). For those interested, you may also request to join our mailing list so that you are aware of any upcoming events: <a href="https://mailman.stanford.edu/mailman/listinfo/eas-workshop">https://mailman.stanford.edu/mailman/listinfo/eas-workshop </a></span></p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>
                                                                                                                      </div>

<meta name="description" content="The Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures offers programs for students who wish to engage with the cultures of China, Japan, and Korea as articulated in language, linguistics, literature, film, cultural studies, and visual arts. Students emerge with a sophisticated understanding of culture as a dynamic process embodied in language and other representational media, especially the verbal and visual forms that are central to humanistic study." />

  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Graduate Program</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-stanford_jsa_layouts-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">
  <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf active-trail active menu-mlid-992"><a href="/graduate-program/graduate-program-overview" class="active-trail active">Overview</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-965"><a href="/graduate-program/applying-graduate-program">Applying to the Graduate Program</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-960"><a href="/graduate-program/master-arts">Master of Arts</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-963"><a href="/graduate-program/phd">Ph.D.</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1160"><a href="/graduate-program/east-asian-linguistics-workshop">East Asian Linguistics Workshop</a></li>

</ul></div>
 </div>

<div id="block-bean-jumpstart-graduate-in-the-spotli" class="clearfix block block-bean well">     <h2>Why am I glad to be a part of EALC?</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="entity entity-bean bean-stanford-postcard clearfix" about="/block/jumpstart-graduate-in-the-spotli" typeof="">

  <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-field-s-postcard-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p class="float-left"><img alt="Image of PhD Grad Student, Kevin Singleton" src="https://ealc.stanford.edu/s3/files/styles/sm-square/public/singletonkevin-phd_1.jpg?itok=VOCR7oN6" /></p>
<p>“Why am I glad to be a part of the EALC? That’s easy enough. The freedom (and resources) to pursue my own academic interests, professors equally attentive to the pursuit of knowledge and the practical exigencies of professional development, a supportive community of graduate students who continue to teach me new things on a daily basis, and opportunities to engage with contemporary authors and scholars hailing from all over the globe. If you have never thought that, say, Japanese linked verse from the 15th century or the popular literature of the early Showa Period could be exciting, I would ask you first to visit our doors.”</p>
<p>-- Kevin Singleton, Japanese PhD Candidate</p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
 </div>
</div>
</div>
 <!-- /.region -->
</div>
        </div>
        <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Graduate Program Overview </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-150" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/graduate-program/graduate-program-overview" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Graduate Program Overview" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary">The Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures offers programs for students who wish to engage with the cultures of China, Japan, and Korea as articulated in language, linguistics, literature, film, cultural studies, and visual arts. Students emerge with a sophisticated understanding of culture as a dynamic process embodied in language and other representational media, especially the verbal and visual forms that are central to humanistic study.</p>
<p>Our department currently offer the following programs:</p>
<ul><li>Master of Arts in Chinese</li>
<li>Master of Arts in Japanese</li>
<li>Doctor of Philosophy in Chinese</li>
<li>Doctor of Philosophy in Chinese, Archaeology Subplan</li>
<li>Doctor of Philosophy in Japanese</li>
<li>Doctor of Philosophy in Japanese, Linguistics Track</li>
</ul><p>All students contemplating application for admission to graduate study must have a creditable undergraduate record. The applicant need not have majored in Chinese or Japanese as an undergraduate, but must have had the equivalent of least three years of training in the language in which he or she intends to specialize, and must also demonstrate a command of English adequate for the pursuit of graduate study. Applicants should not wish merely to acquire or improve language skills, but to pursue study in one of the following fields: Chinese History (pre-modern), Chinese linguistics, Chinese literature, Chinese Philosophy, Japanese cultural history, Japanese literature and Japanese linguistics.</p>
<p>For more information, please explore other pages to learn more about our graduate programs. Please contact our Student Services Officer, <a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/people/staff">Ai Tran</a> (<a href="mailto:aitran@stanford.edu?subject=Question%20about%20East%20Asian%20Languages%20%26%20Cultures'%20Graduate%20Program">aitran@stanford.edu</a>).</p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Master of Arts </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-108" class="node node-stanford-landing-page large-landscape clearfix" about="/graduate-program/master-arts" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Master of Arts" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="summary"><div class="field field-name-field-s-landing-page-lead-text field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Programs in East Asian Languages and Cultures</div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>General Notes:</p>
<ol><li>Our department offers Master of Arts (M.A.) degrees in Chinese and in Japanese. On average, students complete program requirements and receive their degree is two years.</li>
<li>We are unable to offer financial aid to applicants who apply for the M.A., but encourage our students to seek outside funding/fellowships.</li>
<li>Students who wish to spend the first year of graduate study at the Beijing or Yokohama Centers must obtain department approval first.</li>
<li>Candidates for the degree must be in residence at Stanford in California during the final quarter of registration.</li>
<li>A thesis or an annotated translation of a text of suitable literary or historical worth is required for the M.A. degree. Under special circumstances, a paper approved by the graduate adviser may be substituted.</li>
</ol><p>The University's basic requirements for the master's degree, including a 45-unit minimum requirement, are given in the "<a href="http://exploredegrees.stanford.edu/graduatedegrees/">Graduate Degrees</a>" section of the University Bulletin.</p>
</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-landing-page-item field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden large-landscape-view-mode"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/243" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/master-arts/applying-ma"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/photo-1445331552301-94139f242587.jpeg?itok=PKflO3UJ" width="370" height="275" alt="Purple Leaves" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/master-arts/applying-ma" title="Applying to the MA">Applying to the MA</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item odd"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/244" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/deadlines"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/photo-1434130821849-9193eda89c8c.jpeg?itok=dWT0uaxH" width="370" height="275" alt="Paper Lantern" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/deadlines" title="Deadlines">Deadlines</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item even"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/260" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/master-arts/requirements"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/photo-1433259651738-0e74537aa8b5.jpeg?itok=6m0Mq4qn" width="370" height="275" alt="Red Leaves" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/master-arts/requirements" title="Requirements">Requirements</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item odd"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/245" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://files-dev-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/ealc_university_resource_guide.pdf"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/photo-1434704250778-05cf1ad2b03c.jpeg?itok=1_YOZ4MV" width="370" height="275" alt="City at night" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="https://files-dev-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/ealc_university_resource_guide.pdf" title="Resource Guide (PDF)">Resource Guide (PDF)</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Applying to the M.A. </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-141" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/graduate-program/master-arts/applying-ma" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Applying to the M.A." class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-image group_s_postcard_image"><div class="field-collection-container clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-info field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-large-scaled field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/288" typeof="">
  <div class="content">
    <div class="border-simple-nowidth border-shadow"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-scaled/public/chinese-1028101.jpg?itok=n2pTgJcP" width="270" height="180" alt="" /></div></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p><span>The Application Deadline for 2016-17 admissions has passed. Please check back in September for more application details for 2017-18. The deadline submit your application for 2017-18 will be on </span><strong>Tuesday, December 6, 2016</strong><span>, 5:00 pm PST.  </span></p>
<p>Our department offers a Master of Arts degree in Chinese, and Japanese. <span>All students contemplating application for admission to graduate study must have an undergraduate degree from an accredited university. The applicant need not have majored in Chinese or Japanese as an undergraduate, but must have had the equivalent of at least three years of training in the language in which he or she intends to specialize, and must also demonstrate a command of English adequate for the pursuit of graduate study. Applicants should not wish merely to acquire or improve language skills, but to pursue study in one of the following fields: Chinese history (pre-modern), Chinese linguistics, Chinese literature, Chinese philosophy, Japanese cultural history, Japanese literature, and Japanese linguistics.</span></p>
<p><span>For more information regarding the application process and eligibility, please visit <a href="https://gradadmissions.stanford.edu/applying">Stanford's Grad Admissions webpage</a>.</span></p>
<p> <span>Applications must apply online through our University website: </span><a href="https://gradadmissions.stanford.edu/applying/starting-your-application">Stanford Graduate Admissions: Starting Your Application</a>.</p>
<p> </p>
<p> </p>
<p> </p>
<div> </div>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

<div id="block-bean-jumpstart-footer-social-media-0" class="clearfix block block-bean span2">     <h2>Connect</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="entity entity-bean bean-stanford-social-media-connect clearfix" about="/block/jumpstart-footer-social-media--0" typeof="">

  <div class="content">

http://givingtostanford.stanford.edu
1) In the scroll down menus provided, please direct your gift to School of Humanities and Sciences.
2) In the next step, select Dept or Program and specify Asian Languages in the special instruction/designation field below.
You can also mail your contribution to the EALC office. Checks should be made payable to “Stanford University.”
For assistance or more information, please contact:
Connie Chin, Manager, EALC
521 Memorial Way
Stanford, CA 94305
