                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Requirements </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-287" class="node node-stanford-landing-page stanford-medium-square clearfix" about="/graduate-program/master-arts/requirements" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Requirements" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-field-landing-page-item field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden stanford-medium-square-view-mode"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/282" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-stanford_medium_square clearfix">

  
  <div class="postcard-left"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2>Masters of Arts in Chinese</h2></div></div></div><div class="more-link"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-link field-type-link-field field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/master-arts/requirements/master-arts-chinese">Learn more about the MA in Chinese</a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item odd"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/283" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-stanford_medium_square clearfix">

  
  <div class="postcard-left"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2>Master of Arts, Chinese Archaeology Subplan</h2></div></div></div><div class="more-link"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-link field-type-link-field field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/master-arts/requirements/master-arts-chinese-archaeology-subplan">Learn more about the Masters of Arts in Chinese Archaeology</a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item even"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/284" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-stanford_medium_square clearfix">

  
  <div class="postcard-left"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2>Master of Arts in Japanese</h2></div></div></div><div class="more-link"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-link field-type-link-field field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/master-arts/requirements/master-arts-japanese">Learn more about the Masters of Arts in Japanese</a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item odd"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/285" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-stanford_medium_square clearfix">

  
  <div class="postcard-left"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2>Coterminal Master of Arts Programs in East Asian Languages and Cultures</h2></div></div></div><div class="more-link"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-link field-type-link-field field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/master-arts/requirements/coterminal-master-arts-programs-east-asian-languages-and">Learn more about the Coterminal Masters</a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div>

http://givingtostanford.stanford.edu
1) In the scroll down menus provided, please direct your gift to School of Humanities and Sciences.
2) In the next step, select Dept or Program and specify Asian Languages in the special instruction/designation field below.
You can also mail your contribution to the EALC office. Checks should be made payable to “Stanford University.”
For assistance or more information, please contact:
Connie Chin, Manager, EALC
521 Memorial Way
Stanford, CA 94305

  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Graduate Program</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-stanford_jsa_layouts-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">
  <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-992"><a href="/graduate-program/graduate-program-overview">Overview</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-965"><a href="/graduate-program/applying-graduate-program">Applying to the Graduate Program</a></li>
<li class="expanded active-trail menu-mlid-960 dropdown-submenu"><a href="/graduate-program/master-arts" class="active-trail dropdown-toggle" data-toggle="dropdown" data-target="#">Master of Arts</a><ul class="dropdown-menu"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-981"><a href="/graduate-program/master-arts/applying-ma">Applying to the MA</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-982"><a href="/graduate-program/deadlines">M.A. Timeline</a></li>
<li class="last expanded active-trail menu-mlid-1037 dropdown-submenu"><a href="/graduate-program/master-arts/requirements" class="active-trail dropdown-toggle" data-toggle="dropdown" data-target="#">Requirements</a><ul class="dropdown-menu"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-1024"><a href="/graduate-program/master-arts/requirements/master-arts-chinese">Master of Arts in Chinese</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1025"><a href="/graduate-program/master-arts/requirements/master-arts-chinese-archaeology-subplan">Master of Arts in Chinese, Archaeology Subplan</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1026"><a href="/graduate-program/master-arts/requirements/master-arts-japanese">Master of Arts in Japanese</a></li>
<li class="last leaf active-trail active menu-mlid-1027"><a href="/graduate-program/master-arts/requirements/coterminal-master-arts-programs-east-asian-languages-and" class="active-trail active">Coterminal Master of Arts Programs in East Asian Languages and Cultures</a></li>
</ul></li>
</ul></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-963"><a href="/graduate-program/phd">Ph.D.</a></li>

        <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Coterminal Master of Arts Programs in East Asian Languages and Cultures </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-251" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/graduate-program/master-arts/requirements/coterminal-master-arts-programs-east-asian-languages-and" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Coterminal Master of Arts Programs in East Asian Languages and Cultures" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>With department approval, current Stanford undergraduates may apply to combine programs for the B.A. and M.A. degrees in Chinese or Japanese. Prospective applicants must consult with the graduate adviser. Please note the University's general Coterminal Requirements:</p>
<ol><li>Coterminal master’s degree candidates are expected to complete all master’s degree requirements as described in this bulletin. University requirements for the coterminal master’s degree are described on the <a href="https://registrar.stanford.edu/students/coterminal-degree-programs">Coterminal Master’s Program page</a>. University requirements for the master’s degree are described in the "Graduate Degrees" section of this bulletin.</li>
	<li>After accepting admission to this coterminal master’s degree program, students may request transfer of courses from the undergraduate to the graduate career to satisfy requirements for the master’s degree. Transfer of courses to the graduate career requires review and approval of both the undergraduate and graduate programs on a case by case basis.</li>
	<li>Students who wish to spend the first year of graduate study at the Beijing or Yokohama Centers must first obtain department approval.</li>
	<li>In this master’s program, courses taken three quarters prior to the first graduate quarter, or later, are eligible for consideration for transfer to the graduate career. No courses taken prior to the first quarter of the sophomore year may be used to meet master’s degree requirements. Courses may not count for both the Bachelor and Master's degree.</li>
	<li>Course transfers are not possible after the bachelor’s degree has been conferred.</li>
	<li>Stanford University requires that the graduate adviser be assigned in the student’s first graduate quarter even though the undergraduate career may still be open. The University also requires that the Master’s Degree Program Proposal be completed by the student and approved by the department by the end of the student’s first graduate quarter.</li>
</ol></div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->

<meta name="description" content="The M.A. program in Chinese is designed for students with strong academic records and an interest in pursuing postgraduate research in Chinese literature, philosophy, or linguistics, but who have not yet acquired the language skills or disciplinary foundation necessary to enter a Ph.D. program. (Note: Students who wish to pursue advanced language training in preparation for post-graduate research in other fields of Chinese studies are referred to the interdisciplinary M.A. program in the Center for East Asian Studies.)" />

  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Graduate Program</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-stanford_jsa_layouts-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">
  <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-992"><a href="/graduate-program/graduate-program-overview">Overview</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-965"><a href="/graduate-program/applying-graduate-program">Applying to the Graduate Program</a></li>
<li class="expanded active-trail menu-mlid-960 dropdown-submenu"><a href="/graduate-program/master-arts" class="active-trail dropdown-toggle" data-toggle="dropdown" data-target="#">Master of Arts</a><ul class="dropdown-menu"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-981"><a href="/graduate-program/master-arts/applying-ma">Applying to the MA</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-982"><a href="/graduate-program/deadlines">M.A. Timeline</a></li>
<li class="last expanded active-trail menu-mlid-1037 dropdown-submenu"><a href="/graduate-program/master-arts/requirements" class="active-trail dropdown-toggle" data-toggle="dropdown" data-target="#">Requirements</a><ul class="dropdown-menu"><li class="first leaf active-trail active menu-mlid-1024"><a href="/graduate-program/master-arts/requirements/master-arts-chinese" class="active-trail active">Master of Arts in Chinese</a></li>

</ul></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-963"><a href="/graduate-program/phd">Ph.D.</a></li>

</ul></div>
 </div>
</div>
</div>
 <!-- /.region -->
</div>
        </div>
        <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Master of Arts in Chinese </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-244" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/graduate-program/master-arts/requirements/master-arts-chinese" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Master of Arts in Chinese" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-image group_s_postcard_image"><div class="field-collection-container clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-info field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-large-scaled field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/291" typeof="">
  <div class="content">
    <div class="border-simple-nowidth border-shadow"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-scaled/public/photo-1460962784089-6d0f18df898e.jpg?itok=SF1K5RLN" width="270" height="180" alt="" /></div></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>The M.A. program in Chinese is designed for students with strong academic records and an interest in pursuing postgraduate research in Chinese literature, philosophy, or linguistics, but who have not yet acquired the language skills or disciplinary foundation necessary to enter a Ph.D. program. (Note: Students who wish to pursue advanced language training in preparation for post-graduate research in other fields of Chinese studies are referred to the interdisciplinary M.A. program in the Center for East Asian Studies.)</p>
<p>The candidate must finish third-year Chinese, and one course in advanced classical Chinese with a letter grade of 'B' or higher. Placement tests in modern and in classical Chinese will be given for incoming students during orientation week, Autumn Quarter. Those who fail to place into advanced level classical must take beginning classical Chinese. Qualified students may, upon consultation with the graduate adviser, be permitted to certify that they have attained the equivalent level of proficiency by passing examinations.</p>
<h3>Master of Arts in Chinese, Degree Requirements:</h3>
<ol><li>Demonstrate proficiency in both modern and classical Chinese through completion of one of the tracks of third-year Chinese with a letter grade of 'B' or higher:
		<ul><li>CHINLANG 103: Third-Year Modern Chinese, Third Quarter</li>
			<li>CHINGLANG 103B: Third-Year Modern Chinese for Bilingual Students, Third Quarter</li>
		</ul></li>
	<li>One of three advanced classical Chinese courses:
		<ul><li>CHINA 208 (formerly CHINLIT 221): Advanced Classical Chinese: Philosophical Texts</li>
			<li>CHINA 209 (formerly CHINLIT 222): Advanced Classical Chinese: Historical Narration</li>
			<li>CHINA 210 (formerly CHINLIT 223): Advanced Classical Chinese: Literary Essays</li>
		</ul></li>
	<li>Complete CHINA 201 (formerly CHINLIT 201): Proseminar: Bibliographic and Research Methods in Chinese Studies with a letter grade of 'B' or higher</li>
	<li>Four courses with the CHINA subject code (formerly CHINGEN or CHINLIT) numbered above 200</li>
	<li>Two upper-division or graduate-level courses in fields such as Chinese anthropology, art history, history, philosophy, politics, religious studies, or another relevant field, as approved by the graduate adviser in consultation with the student's individual adviser</li>
	<li>Complete CHINA 299 (fomerly CHINLIT 299): Master's Thesis or Translation, and submit the Master's Thesis to the department.</li>
</ol><p> </p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Note:</strong> As a general rule of thumb, students should check the Stanford Bulletin Archives to make sure that he or she completes requirements for the year that they were martriculated. <a href="http://exploredegrees.stanford.edu/archive/">Click here for archived Stanford University Bulletins.</a></p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

The subplan is declared on Axess. Subplans are printed on the transcript and the diploma and are elected via the Declaration of Change to a Field of Study form." />

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Master of Arts, Chinese Archaeology Subplan </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-245" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/graduate-program/master-arts/requirements/master-arts-chinese-archaeology-subplan" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Master of Arts, Chinese Archaeology Subplan" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-image group_s_postcard_image"><div class="field-collection-container clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-info field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-large-scaled field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/292" typeof="">
  <div class="content">
    <div class="border-simple-nowidth border-shadow"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-scaled/public/terracotta-1028109.jpg?itok=gA-11XKm" width="270" height="405" alt="" /></div></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>The M.A. program in Chinese, Archaeology Subplan, is designed for students with an interest in pursuing postgraduate research in Chinese archaeology, but who have not yet acquired the language skills or disciplinary foundation necessary to enter a Ph.D. program. The subplan is declared on Axess. Subplans are printed on the transcript and the diploma and are elected via the <a href="https://stanford.app.box.com/v/grad-subplan-change" rel="nofollow">Declaration of Change to a Field of Study form</a>.</p>
<p><span>Master of Arts in Chinese, Archaeology Subplan Degree Requirements:</span></p>
<ol><li>Proficiency in both modern and classical Chinese by completing
		<ul><li>Third-Year Chinese through CHINLANG 103 with a minimum grade of 'B+'</li>
			<li>One of three advanced classical Chinese courses
				<ul><li>CHINLIT 221: Advanced Classical Chinese: Philosophical Texts</li>
					<li>CHINLIT 222: Advanced Classical Chinese: Historical Narration, or</li>
					<li>CHINLIT 223: Advanced Classical Chinese: Literary Essays</li>
				</ul></li>
			<li><span> </span><strong>NOTE:</strong> Qualified students may, upon consultation with the graduate adviser, be permitted to certify that they have attained the equivalent level of proficiency by passing examinations or presenting documentary evidence of attendance at a bachelor’s institution wherein Chinese is the language of instruction. Exemptions may also be granted to students who study prehistoric archaeology. Instead, these students should take required coursework relating to archaeology, which is offered through the <a href="https://archaeology.stanford.edu/">Stanford Archaeology Center</a>. For details students should consult with the supervisor or the graduate adviser.</li>
		</ul></li>
	<li>Complete 45 units, including the following four graduate level CHINGEN or ANTHRO subject code courses, appropriate to the Chinese Archaeology track. All courses must be passed with a minimum grade of ‘B+’.
		<ul><li>Required graduate level CHINGEN and ANTHRO courses
				<ul><li>CHINGEN 218: Emergence of Chinese Civilization from Caves to Palaces</li>
					<li>CHINGEN 241: Constructing National History in East Asian Archaeology</li>
					<li>ANTHRO 303: Introduction to Archaeological Theory</li>
					<li>ANTHRO 307: Archaeological Methods</li>
				</ul></li>
			<li>Two upper-division or graduate-level courses in fields such as Chinese anthropology, archaeology, art history, history, philosophy, political science and religious studies, as approved by the graduate adviser in consultation with the student’s individual adviser.</li>
			<li>Submit the Master's Thesis.</li>
		</ul></li>
</ol><p> </p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Note: </strong><span>As a general rule of thumb, students should check the Stanford Bulletin Archives to make sure that he or she completes requirements for the year that they were martriculated. </span><a href="http://exploredegrees.stanford.edu/archive/">Click here for archived Stanford University Bulletins</a>.</p>
<p> </p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>

<meta name="description" content="The M.A. program in Japanese is designed for students with strong academic records and an interest in pursuing postgraduate research in Japanese literature, cultural history, or linguistics, but who have not yet acquired the language skills or disciplinary foundation necessary to enter a Ph.D. program. Note: Students who wish to pursue advanced language training in preparation for postgraduate research in other fields of Japanese studies are referred to the interdisciplinary M.A. program in the Center for East Asian Studies." />

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Master of Arts in Japanese </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-250" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/graduate-program/master-arts/requirements/master-arts-japanese" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Master of Arts in Japanese" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-image group_s_postcard_image"><div class="field-collection-container clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-info field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-large-scaled field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/293" typeof="">
  <div class="content">
    <div class="border-simple-nowidth border-shadow"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-scaled/public/2014-07-20_19.10.29.jpg?itok=NBAeCQ75" width="270" height="203" alt="" /></div></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>The M.A. program in Japanese is designed for students with strong academic records and an interest in pursuing postgraduate research in Japanese literature, cultural history, or linguistics, but who have not yet acquired the language skills or disciplinary foundation necessary to enter a Ph.D. program. <strong>Note:</strong> Students who wish to pursue advanced language training in preparation for postgraduate research in other fields of Japanese studies are referred to the interdisciplinary M.A. program in the Center for East Asian Studies.</p>
<p>Master of Arts in Japanese, Degree Requirements:</p>
<ol><li>Complete third-year modern Japanese.
		<ul><li>JAPANLNG 101</li>
			<li>JAPANLNG 102</li>
			<li>JAPANLNG 103</li>
		</ul></li>
	<li>Complete fourth-year Japanese and Classical Japanese with a grade of 'B' or higher.
		<ul><li>Fourth-year Japanese:
				<ul><li>JAPANLNG 211: Fourth-Year Japanese, First Quarter</li>
					<li>JAPANLNG 212: Fourth-Year Japanese, Second Quarter</li>
					<li>JAPANLNG 213: Fourth-Year Japanese, Third Quarter</li>
				</ul></li>
			<li>Classical Japanese
				<ul><li>JAPANLIT 246: Introduction to Premodern Japanese</li>
					<li>JAPANLIT 247: Readings in Premodern Japanese</li>
				</ul></li>
			<li>Note: qualified students may, upon consultation with the graduate adviser, be permitted to certify that they have attained the equivalent level of proficiency by passing examinations. Please obtain this permission in writing and submit it to the Student Services Officer.</li>
		</ul></li>
	<li>Complete the following with a letter grade of 'B' or higher:
		<ul><li>four adviser-approved courses in Japanese literature, culture, or linguistics from among the offerings of the Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures, not including courses taken to fulfill the language requirement.</li>
			<li>Complete JAPANLIT 201 Proseminar: Introduction to Graduate Study in Japanese.</li>
			<li>Two upper-division or graduate-level courses in fields such as Japanese anthropology, art history, history, philosophy, politics, and religion, as approved by the graduate adviser in consultation with the student's individual adviser.</li>
		</ul></li>
	<li>Enroll in JAPANLIT 299: Master's Thesis or Translation, and complete the Master's Thesis</li>
</ol><p> </p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Note:</strong><span> As a general rule of thumb, students should check the Stanford Bulletin Archives to make sure that he or she completes requirements for the year that they were martriculated. </span><a href="http://exploredegrees.stanford.edu/archive/">Click here for archived Stanford University Bulletins.</a></p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

        <div id="footer-content" class="row-fluid footer-content"> <div class="region region-footer clearfix">
  <div id="block-menu-menu-footer-about-menu" class="clearfix block block-menu span2">     <h2>About</h2>
      <div class="content"> <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf"><a href="/about/contact/map-and-directions">Location</a></li>
<li class="last leaf"><a href="/about/giving">Make a Gift</a></li>
</ul> </div>

<div id="block-menu-menu-footer-academics-menu" class="clearfix block block-menu span2">     <h2>Academics</h2>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Ph.D. </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-111" class="node node-stanford-landing-page large-landscape clearfix" about="/graduate-program/phd" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Ph.D." class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="field-collection-container clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-info field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-12-col-banner field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/295" typeof="">
  <div class="content">
    <div class="border-simple border-shadow border-bottom"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/12-col-banner/public/photo-1431608660976-4fe5bcc2112c.jpg?itok=zP9dDzYk" width="1170" height="370" alt="" /></div></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div></div><div class="summary"><div class="field field-name-field-s-landing-page-lead-text field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Doctor of Philosophy Programs in East Asian Languages and Cultures</div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary">Our department offers doctoral programs in Chinese and Japanese:</p>
<ul><li>Doctor of Philosophy in Chinese</li>
	<li>Doctor of Philosophy in Chinese, Archaeology Subplan</li>
	<li>Doctor of Philosophy in Japanese</li>
	<li>Doctor of Philosophy in Japanese, Linguistics Track</li>
	<li>Doctor of Philosophy Minor in East Asian Languages and Cultures</li>
</ul><p>Candidates for the degree are expected to acquire a thorough familiarity with Chinese or Japanese literature and linguistics, an adequate command of relevant languages, and a comprehensive knowledge of East Asian history, social institutions, and thought. The University's basic requirements for the Ph.D. program are given in the "Graduate Degrees" section of the <a href="http://www.stanford.edu/dept/registrar/bulletin/">Stanford Bulletin</a>.</p>
<p> </p>
<h3>Doctor of Philosophy in Chinese</h3>
<p>The Ph.D. program in Chinese is designed to prepare students for a doctoral degree in Chinese literature, philosophy, or linguistics. Applicants must have a minimum of three years of Chinese language study at Stanford or the equivalent to be considered for admission. Ph.D. students will complete the M.A. as described above on the way to advancing to Ph.D. candidacy (<a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/phd/requirements/phd-chinese">see Requirements for the Ph.D. in Chinese here</a>). The majority of required course work for Ph.D. students demands the ability to read primary and secondary materials in Chinese. Advanced standing may be considered for students entering the Ph.D. program who have already completed an M.A. in Chinese literature or linguistics elsewhere only in cases when the level of prior course work and research is deemed equivalent to departmental requirements for the Ph.D. All courses must be taken for a letter grade.</p>
<p> </p>
<h3>Doctor of Philosophy in Chinese, Archaeology Subplan</h3>
<p>The Ph.D. program in Chinese Archaeology is designed to prepare students for a doctoral degree in Chinese archaeology. Applicants must have a minimum of three years of Chinese language study at Stanford or the equivalent to be considered for admission. Students on the Ph.D. track will complete the degree requirements for the Master of Arts in Chinese, Archaeology Subplan, on the way to advancing to Ph.D. candidacy (<a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/master-arts/requirements/master-arts-chinese-archaeology-subplan">For Chinese Archaeology M.A. requirements, click here</a>). Advanced standing may be considered for students entering the Ph.D. program who have already completed an M.A. in archaeology or anthropology elsewhere only in cases when the level of prior course work and research is deemed equivalent to departmental requirements for the Ph.D. track. All courses must be taken for a letter grade. Subplans are printed on the transcript and diploma and are elected via the <a href="https://stanford.app.box.com/v/grad-subplan-change" rel="nofollow">Declaration or Change to a Field of Study form.</a></p>
<p> </p>
<h3>Doctor of Philosophy in Japanese</h3>
<p>The Ph.D. program in Japanese is designed to prepare students for a doctoral degree in Japanese literature, cultural history, or linguistics. Applicants must have a minimum of three years of Japanese language study at Stanford or the equivalent to be considered for admission. Ph.D. students will complete M.A. requirements on the way to advancing to Ph.D. candidacy (see department guidelines for admission to candidacy above). The majority of required course work for Ph.D. students demands the ability to read primary and secondary materials in Japanese. Advanced standing may be considered for students entering the Ph.D. program who have already completed an M.A. in Japanese literature or linguistics elsewhere only in cases when the level of prior course work and research is deemed equivalent to departmental requirements for the Ph.D. All courses must be taken for a letter grade.</p>
<p> </p>
<h3>Doctor of Philosophy in Japanese, Linguistics Track</h3>
<p>The Ph.D. program in Japanese, Linguistics Track, is designed for students who wish to specialize in Japanese linguistics. Applicants must have a minimum of three years of Japanese language study at Stanford or the equivalent to be considered for admission. Ph.D. students will complete the Master of Arts in Japanese requirements on the way to advancing to Ph.D. candidacy (see department requirements for the Master of Arts in Japanese). Candidates are also expected to take relevant courses in linguistics, and other supporting fields. These fields are to be determined with the consultation of the student’s primary adviser, may include applied linguistics, Chinese linguistics, psychology, education anthropology, sociology, etc. Like the Japanese Ph.D. program, Ph.D. candidates on the Japanese Linguistics Track must be able to read primary and secondary materials in Japanese. Advanced standing may be considered for students entering the Ph.D. program who have already have already completed an M.A. in Japanese literature or linguistics elsewhere only in cases when the level of prior course work and research is deemed equivalent to departmental requirements for the Ph.D. All courses must be taken for a letter grade.</p>
<p> </p>
<h3>Doctor of Philosophy Minor in East Asian Languages and Cultures</h3>
<p>A student taking a Ph.D. minor in Chinese or Japanese must complete at least 30 units of work within the department at the 200 and 300 level, chosen in consultation with a department adviser. The student must take either CHINLIT 201 Proseminar: Bibliographic and Research Methods in Chinese Studies or JAPANLIT 201 Proseminar: Introduction to Graduate Study in Japanese unless the department is satisfied that work done elsewhere has provided similar training. The student must also pass a written examination in the Chinese or Japanese language.</p>
</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-landing-page-item field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden large-landscape-view-mode"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/281" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/phd/applying-phd"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/photo-1454596561026-ffcf604705c8.jpeg?itok=a9OZKO66" width="370" height="275" alt="Paper Lanterns" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/phd/applying-phd" title="Applying to the Ph.D.">Applying to the Ph.D.</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item odd"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/246" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/phd/guidelines-graduate"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/graduation_balloons.png?itok=jYwgAL75" width="370" height="275" alt="" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/phd/guidelines-graduate" title="Guidelines to Graduate">Guidelines to Graduate</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item even"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/247" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/phd/requirements"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/photo-1459570401946-7f5fb8607d80.jpeg?itok=sF_-D3pO" width="370" height="275" alt="paper lantern in alley" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/phd/requirements" title="Requirements">Requirements</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item odd"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/248" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/phd/phd-minor"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/photo-1445264755539-41ee51f9e8f1.jpeg?itok=xNyIv0Ir" width="370" height="275" alt="Red Umbrella" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/phd/phd-minor" title="Ph.D. Minor">Ph.D. Minor</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item even"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/249" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://files-dev-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/ta_handbook_ealc_05062015.pdf"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/rula-sibai-pink-flowers.jpg?itok=BNHmf-XS" width="370" height="275" alt="Pink Flowers" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="https://files-dev-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/ta_handbook_ealc_05062015.pdf" title="TA Handbook (PDF)">TA Handbook (PDF)</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item odd"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/250" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/phd/phd-handbook"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/u8gbf8bbsgy3ycihyzei_img_8737.jpg?itok=9yD8UsvN" width="370" height="275" alt="Paper Lantern" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/phd/phd-handbook" title="Ph.D. Handbook">Ph.D. Handbook</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item even"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/251" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/phd/overseas-studies"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/photo-1438919848714-206d008562bb.jpeg?itok=LIGtwNOu" width="370" height="275" alt="" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/phd/overseas-studies" title="Overseas Studies">Overseas Studies</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Applying to the Ph.D. </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-127" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/graduate-program/phd/applying-phd" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Applying to the Ph.D." class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p><span>The Application Deadline for 2016-17 admissions has passed. Please check back in September for more application details for 2017-18. The deadline submit your application for 2017-18 will be on </span><strong>Tuesday, December 6, 2016</strong><span>, 5:00 pm PST.  </span></p>
<p>Our department offers Doctoral Programs in Chinese, and Japanese. <span>All students contemplating application for admission to graduate study must have an undergraduate degree from an accredited university. Candidates for the degree are expected to acquire a thorough familiarity with Chinese or Japanese literature and linguistics, an adequate command of relevant languages, and a comprehensive knowledge of East Asian history, social institutions, and thought. The applicant need not have majored in Chinese or Japanese as an undergraduate, but must have had the equivalent of at least three years of training in the language in which he or she intends to specialize, and must also demonstrate a command of English adequate for the pursuit of graduate study. Applicants should not wish merely to acquire or improve language skills, but to pursue study in one of the following fields:</span></p>
<ul><li><span>Doctor of Philosophy in Chinese</span></li>
	<li><span>Doctor of Philosophy in Chinese, Archaeology Subplan</span></li>
	<li>Doctor of Philosophy in Japanese</li>
	<li>Doctor of Philosophy in Japanese, Linguistics Track</li>
</ul><h2>Admission to Candidacy</h2>
<p>Students are evaluated by the graduate faculty during their second year at Stanford. The evaluation is based on a research paper of 25-30 pages documented and with a bibliography, written for an EALC major seminar above the 200 level. Students are also expected to have a GPA of at least 'A-' and demonstrate satisfactory work as a teaching assistant. If the faculty have serious doubts about a student's ability to work for the Ph.D., they convey this to the student. During the subsequent Spring Quarter, the faculty formally decide by vote whether a student should be admitted to candidacy for the Ph.D. or offered an extension. In cases of extension of pre-candidacy, a clear plan is developed for the student, and a reassessment completed within two academic quarters.</p>
<p>If a student goes to the Inter-University Program for Chinese Language Studies (IUP) at Tsinghua University or the Inter-University Center (IUC) for Japanese Language Studies in Yokohama during the first two years of study, the department may consider an extension for admission to candidacy. The timing of the evaluation of a student admitted with an M.A. in East Asian Studies is decided on an individual basis.</p>
<p>Candidacy is a milestone different from the comprehensive exams, which are regularly held in the third year. Mastery of the field exams is not to be equated with the potential for doing research. Admission to candidacy indicates that the department faculty consider the student qualified to pursue a program of study leading to the Ph.D.</p>
<p><span>For more information regarding the application process and eligibility, please visit <a href="https://gradadmissions.stanford.edu/applying">Stanford's Grad Admissions webpage</a>.</span></p>
<p> <span>Applicants must apply online through our University website: </span><a href="https://gradadmissions.stanford.edu/applying/starting-your-application">Stanford Graduate Admissions: Starting Your Application</a>.</p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->

<li class="leaf active-trail active menu-mlid-997"><a href="/graduate-program/phd/phd-minor" class="active-trail active">Ph.D. Minor</a></li>
<li class="last leaf menu-mlid-1029"><a href="https://files-dev-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/ta_handbook_ealc_05062015.pdf" title="">TA Handbook (PDF)</a></li>

        <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Ph.D. Minor </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-155" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/graduate-program/phd/phd-minor" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Ph.D. Minor" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary">The Department offers a Ph.D. Minor in East Asian Languages and Cultures</p>
<div>A student taking a Ph.D. minor in Chinese or Japanese must complete at least 30 units of work within the department at the 200 and 300 level, chosen in consultation with a department adviser. The student must take either CHINLIT 201 (Proseminar: Bibliographic and Research Methods in Chinese Studies) or JAPANLIT 201 (Proseminar: Introduction to Graduate Study in Japanese) unless the department is satisfied that work done elsewhere has provided similar training. The student must also pass a written examination in the Chinese or Japanese language.</div>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

<div id="block-bean-jumpstart-footer-contact-block" class="clearfix block block-bean span2">     <h2>Contact Us</h2>

  <div id="block-stanford-ssp-stanford-ssp-login-block" class="clearfix block block-stanford-ssp">     <h2>SUNetID Login</h2>

2) In the next step, select Dept or Program and specify Asian Languages in the special instruction/designation field below.
You can also mail your contribution to the EALC office. Checks should be made payable to “Stanford University.”

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Ph.D. Requirements </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-154" class="node node-stanford-landing-page stanford-medium-square clearfix" about="/graduate-program/phd/phd-requirements" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Ph.D. Requirements" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-field-landing-page-item field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden stanford-medium-square-view-mode"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/273" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-stanford_medium_square clearfix">

  
  <div class="postcard-left"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2>Ph.D. in Chinese</h2></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-description field-type-text-long field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>The Ph.D. program in Chinese is designed to prepare students for a doctoral degree in Chinese literature, philosophy, or linguistics.</p>
</div></div></div><div class="more-link"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-link field-type-link-field field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/phd/requirements/phd-chinese">Learn More</a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item odd"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/274" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-stanford_medium_square clearfix">

  
  <div class="postcard-left"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2>Ph.D., Chinese Archaeology Subplan</h2></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-description field-type-text-long field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>The Ph.D. program in Chinese Archaeology is designed to prepare students for a doctoral degree in Chinese archaeology.</p>
</div></div></div><div class="more-link"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-link field-type-link-field field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://dev.ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/phd/requirements/phd-chinese-archaeology-subplan">Learn more</a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item even"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/277" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-stanford_medium_square clearfix">

  
  <div class="postcard-left"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2> Ph.D. in Japanese Literature</h2></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-description field-type-text-long field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Ph.D. in Japanese literature.</p>
</div></div></div><div class="more-link"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-link field-type-link-field field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://dev.ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/phd/requirements/literature-track">Learn more</a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item odd"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/276" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-stanford_medium_square clearfix">

  
  <div class="postcard-left"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2>Ph.D., Japanese Linguistics Track</h2></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-description field-type-text-long field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Focus in Japanese linguistics.</p>
</div></div></div><div class="more-link"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-link field-type-link-field field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://dev.ealc.stanford.edu/graduate-program/phd/requirements/linguistics-track">Learn more</a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>

            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Page Not Found </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-40" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/404" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Page Not Found" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary">Oops! We can't find that page!</p>
<p class="summary">We have a new site and things have moved around a bit. Here are some good places to start.</p>
<h2>Starting points</h2>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Linguistics Track </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-274" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/graduate-program/phd/requirements/linguistics-track" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Linguistics Track" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary">The Ph.D. program in Japanese is designed to prepare students for a doctoral degree in Japanese literature, cultural history, or linguistics.</p>
<p>Applicants must have a minimum of three years of Japanese language study at Stanford or the equivalent to be considered for admission. Ph.D. students will complete M.A. requirements on the way to advancing to Ph.D. candidacy (see department guidelines for admission to candidacy above). The majority of required course work for Ph.D. students demands the ability to read primary and secondary materials in Japanese. Advanced standing may be considered for students entering the Ph.D. program who have already completed an M.A. in Japanese literature or linguistics elsewhere only in cases when the level of prior course work and research is deemed equivalent to departmental requirements for the Ph.D. All courses must be taken for a letter grade.</p>
<p>A candidate specializing in Japanese linguistics must fulfill the following requirements:</p>
<ol><li>Demonstrate proficiency in both modern and classical Japanese language by completing the following courses, or by demonstrating an equivalent level of linguistic attainment by passing the appropriate certifying examinations:
		<ol><li>Fourth-year Japanese through JAPANLANG 213</li>
			<li>Classical Japanese through JAPANLIT 246 and 247.</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li>Demonstrate proficiency in at least one supporting language, to be chosen in consultation with the primary adviser according to the candidate's specific research goals. Reading proficiency must be certified through a written examination or an appropriate amount of course work, to be determined on a case-by-case basis. When deemed necessary by the student's adviser(s), working knowledge of a third language may also be required.</li>
	<li>Complete six adviser-approved courses numbered above 200 from among the offerings of the Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures.
		<ol><li>At least one of these six courses must be advanced seminars numbered above 300. Please note:</li>
			<li>At least one of these six courses must deal with Japanese literature.</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li>Complete five upper-division or graduate-level courses in linguistics and other supporting fields. These, to be determined in consultation with the student's primary adviser, may include applied linguistics, Chinese linguistics, psychology, education, anthropology, sociology, etc.</li>
	<li>Complete JAPANLIT 279: Research in Japanese Linguistics.</li>
	<li>Submit two qualifying papers presenting substantial research in two different subfields of Japanese linguistics.</li>
	<li>Submit an annotated bibliography pertaining to the topic of dissertation.</li>
	<li>Demonstrate pedagogical proficiency by serving as a teaching assistant for a minimum of one quarter and taking DLCL 301, The Learning and Teaching of Second Language.</li>
	<li>Pass the University Oral Examination. The candidate is examined on questions related to the dissertation after acceptable parts of it have been completed in draft form.</li>
	<li>Submit a dissertation demonstrating ability to undertake original research based on primary and secondary materials in Japanese.</li>
</ol></div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title">  Literature Track </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-276" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/graduate-program/phd/requirements/literature-track" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content=" Literature Track" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary">The Ph.D. program in Japanese is designed to prepare students for a doctoral degree in Japanese literature, cultural history, or linguistics.</p>
<p>Applicants must have a minimum of three years of Japanese language study at Stanford or the equivalent to be considered for admission. Ph.D. students will complete M.A. requirements on the way to advancing to Ph.D. candidacy (see department guidelines for admission to candidacy above). The majority of required course work for Ph.D. students demands the ability to read primary and secondary materials in Japanese. Advanced standing may be considered for students entering the Ph.D. program who have already completed an M.A. in Japanese literature or linguistics elsewhere only in cases when the level of prior course work and research is deemed equivalent to departmental requirements for the Ph.D. All courses must be taken for a letter grade.</p>
<p>For the Ph.D. in Japanese literature, the candidate must fulfill the following requirements:</p>
<ol><li>Demonstrate proficiency in both modern and classical Japanese language by completing the following courses, or by demonstrating an equivalent level of linguistic attainment by passing the appropriate certifying examinations:
		<ol><li>Fourth-year Japanese through JAPANLANG 213 (Fourth-Year Japanese, Third Quarter)</li>
			<li>Classical Japanese through JAPANLIT 246 and 247.</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li>Demonstrate proficiency in at least one supporting language, to be chosen in consultation with the primary adviser according to the candidate's specific research goals. Reading proficiency must be certified through a written examination or an appropriate amount of course work, to be determined on a case-by-case basis. When deemed necessary by the student's adviser(s), working knowledge of a third language may also be required. Students concentrating in classical Japanese literature are normally expected to fulfill this requirement by completingkanbun study in:
		<ol><li>JAPANLIT 248 and/or 249, or</li>
			<li>First-year Classical Chinese, taking the following three courses: CHINLIT 125, 126, and 127</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li>Complete eight adviser-approved courses numbered above 200 from among the offerings of the Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures. Please note:
		<ol><li>At least four of these eight courses must be advanced seminars numbered above 300</li>
			<li>At least one of these eight courses must deal with Japanese linguistics.</li>
			<li>For students focusing on modern literature, at least two of these eight courses must deal with premodern material, and for students focusing on premodern literature, at least two of the eight courses must deal with modern material.</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li>Complete two upper-division or graduate-level courses each in two supporting fields, for a total of four courses outside of Japanese literature or linguistics. Supporting fields, to be determined in consultation with the student's primary adviser, may include Japanese anthropology, art, history, philosophy, politics, religious studies, Chinese literature, comparative literature, etc.</li>
	<li>Complete JAPANLIT 201, Introduction to Graduate Study in Japanese.</li>
	<li>Pass a comprehensive qualifying examination that tests the candidate's breadth and depth in the primary field of research and methodological competence in the relevant discipline.</li>
	<li>Demonstrate pedagogical proficiency by serving as a teaching assistant for a minimum of one quarter and taking DLCL 301, The Learning and Teaching of Second Languages.</li>
	<li>Give oral defense of dissertation proposal by first quarter of fourth year.</li>
	<li>Pass the University Oral Examination. General regulations governing the oral examination are found in the "Graduate Degrees" section of the University Bulletin. The candidate is examined on questions related to the dissertation after acceptable parts of it have been completed in draft form.</li>
	<li>Submit a dissertation demonstrating ability to undertake original research based on primary and secondary materials in Japanese.</li>
</ol></div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

<div id="block-menu-menu-footer-people-menu" class="clearfix block block-menu span2">     <h2>People</h2>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Ph.D. in Chinese </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-281" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/graduate-program/phd/requirements/phd-chinese" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Ph.D. in Chinese" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary">The Ph.D. program in Chinese is designed to prepare students for a doctoral degree in Chinese literature, philosophy, or linguistics.</p>
<p>Applicants must have a minimum of three years of Chinese language study at Stanford or the equivalent to be considered for admission. Ph.D. students will complete the M.A. (as described in the M.A. requirements section on this website) on the way to advancing to Ph.D. candidacy. The majority of required course work for Ph.D. students demands the ability to read primary and secondary materials in Chinese. Advanced standing may be considered for students entering the Ph.D. program who have already completed an M.A. in Chinese literature or linguistics elsewhere only in cases when the level of prior course work and research is deemed equivalent to departmental requirements for the Ph.D. All courses must be taken for a letter grade.</p>
<p>For a Ph.D. in Chinese, a candidate must fulfill the following requirements:</p>
<ol><li>Complete the department's requirements for the M.A. in Chinese and two of three advanced classical Chinese Courses: CHINLIT 221, Advanced Classical Chinese: Philosophical Texts; CHINLIT 222, Advanced Classical Chinese: Historical Narration; or CHINLIT 223, Advanced Classical Chinese: Literary Essays. All incoming Ph.D. students must take a placement test in classical Chinese held during Orientation Week of fall quarter. Those who fail to place into the advanced level must take Beginning Classical Chinese.</li>
	<li>Demonstrate proficiency in at least one supporting language, to be chosen in consultation with the primary adviser according to the candidate's specific research goals. Reading proficiency must be certified through a written examination or an appropriate amount of coursework, to be determined on a case-by-case basis. When deemed necessary by the student's adviser(s), working knowledge of a third language may also be required.</li>
	<li>Students in Chinese literature must take at least one Chinese linguistics course, and linguistics students must take at least one literature course.  One linguistics course is CHINA 291:  Structure of Modern Chinese.</li>
	<li>Complete two relevant seminars at the 300 level. These seminars must be in different subjects.</li>
	<li>Pass a set of three comprehensive written examinations, one of which tests the candidate's methodological competence in the relevant discipline. The remaining two fields are chosen, with the approval of the graduate adviser in consultation with the student's individual adviser, from the following: archaeolology, anthropology, art, Chinese literature, history, Japanese literature, linguistics, philosophy, and religion. With the adviser's approval, a Ph.D. minor in a supporting field may be deemed equivalent to the completion of one of these three examinations.</li>
	<li>Demonstrate pedagogical proficiency by serving as a teaching assistant for a minimum of one quarter, and taking DLCL 301, The Learning and Teaching of Second Languages.</li>
	<li>Pass the University Oral Examination — General regulations governing the oral examination are found in the "Graduate Degrees" section of the University Bulletin. The candidate is examined on questions related to the dissertation after acceptable parts of it have been completed in draft form.</li>
	<li>Submit a dissertation demonstrating ability to undertake original research based on primary materials in Chinese.</li>
</ol></div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Graduate Program</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-stanford_jsa_layouts-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">

<li class="leaf active-trail active menu-mlid-1034"><a href="/graduate-program/phd/requirements/phd-chinese-archaeology-subplan" class="active-trail active">Ph.D., Chinese Archaeology Subplan</a></li>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Ph.D., Chinese Archaeology Subplan </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-280" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/graduate-program/phd/requirements/phd-chinese-archaeology-subplan" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Ph.D., Chinese Archaeology Subplan" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary">The Ph.D. program in Chinese Archaeology is designed to prepare students for a doctoral degree in Chinese archaeology.</p>
<p>Applicants must have a minimum of three years of Chinese language study at Stanford or the equivalent to be considered for admission. Students on the Ph.D. track will complete the M.A. (as described in the M.A requirements section on this website) on the way to advancing to Ph.D. candidacy. Advanced standing may be considered for students entering the Ph.D. program who have already completed an M.A. in archaeology or anthropology elsewhere only in cases when the level of prior course work and research is deemed equivalent to departmental requirements for the Ph.D. track. All courses must be taken for a letter grade. Subplans are printed on the transcript and diploma and are elected via the "Declaration or Change to a Field of Study" form.</p>
<p> </p>
<p>For a Ph.D. in Chinese Archaeology, a candidate must fulfill the following requirements:</p>
<ol><li>Complete one of three advanced classical Chinese courses (CHINLIT 221, 222, or 223) and the requirements for the M.A. Qualified students may, upon consultation with the graduate adviser, be permitted to certify that they have attained the equivalent level of proficiency by passing examinations or presenting documentary evidence. Exemptions may be granted to students who study prehistoric archaeology. Instead, these students should take coursework offered in the Stanford Archaeology Center. Consult with graduate adviser.</li>
	<li>Demonstrate proficiency in at least one supporting foreign language (in addition to Chinese and English), or in a laboratory skill, to be chosen in consultation with the primary adviser according to the candidate's specific research goals. Proficiency (in language(s) and/or laboratory skills) must be certified through a written examination or an appropriate amount of coursework, to be determined on a case-by-case basis.</li>
	<li>Six graduate level CHINGEN or ANTHRO courses appropriate to the Chinese Archaeology track, as approved by the adviser.</li>
	<li>Serve as a teaching assistant for two quarters and research assistant in an archaeology laboratory for two quarters.</li>
	<li>Pass qualifying examinations in Chinese archaeology.</li>
	<li>Pass University oral examination. The candidate is examined on questions related to the dissertation after acceptable parts of it have been completed in draft form.</li>
	<li>Submit a dissertation demonstrating ability to undertake original research based on primary materials in Chinese or data related to China.</li>
</ol></div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

          <div class="row-fluid"><div class="region region-sidebar-first clearfix">
  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Graduate Program</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-stanford_jsa_layouts-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">
  <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-992"><a href="/graduate-program/graduate-program-overview">Overview</a></li>
