<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-960"><a href="/graduate-program/master-arts">Master of Arts</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-963"><a href="/graduate-program/phd">Ph.D.</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1160"><a href="/graduate-program/east-asian-linguistics-workshop">East Asian Linguistics Workshop</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1000"><a href="/graduate-program/east-asian-studies-workshop">East Asian Studies Workshop</a></li>
<li class="last expanded active-trail active menu-mlid-1036 dropdown-submenu"><a href="/graduate-program/resources-current-graduate-students" class="active-trail dropdown-toggle active" data-toggle="dropdown" data-target="#">Resources for Current Graduate Students</a><ul class="dropdown-menu"><li class="first last leaf menu-mlid-1028"><a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/18k7R0SYHdgoSWn_bxebeo0Oek2eic07-sngs_V5U0Bw/edit?usp=sharing" title="">EALC Graduate Student Handbook</a></li>
</ul></li>
</ul></div>

        <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Resources for Current Graduate Students </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-286" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/graduate-program/resources-current-graduate-students" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Resources for Current Graduate Students" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><h2>Departmental Resources</h2>
<ul><li><strong>Department Travel Grant:</strong> Our department has set aside travel funds for graduate students who wish to travel to conferences outside of Stanford University. Students must be presenting their paper/research at these events, and is limited to two travel grants per academic year from our department. Graduate students should download the Department Travel Grant and submit it to Connie Chin (<a href="mailto:csquare@stanford.edu" rel="nofollow">csquare@stanford.edu</a>) for review. Our department will grant up to $500.00 in funds for travel grants. Please note that this is a limited resource, and Advanced students will get priority.</li>
	<li><strong>Copy and Printing Needs:</strong> students belonging to the East Asian Languages and Cultures Department may make up to 1,000 copies on the departmental copier per year. To set up a PIN, see Connie. Students may also print from our deparmental printers, available in the copy room on the basement level.</li>
	<li><strong>Shared Office Space:</strong> Advanced graduate students who are writing dissertations and teaching assistants will be assigned shared offices. Students should make requests for office space with Connie Chin <span>(</span><a href="mailto:csquare@stanford.edu" rel="nofollow">csquare@stanford.edu</a><span>)</span>.</li>
</ul><h2>Stanford University Resources</h2>
<ul><li><span><a href="http://ceas.stanford.edu/students/ceas-prizes-and-fellowships.php">Center for East Asian Studies (CEAS):</a> CEAS provides limited funding opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students with an interest in East Asian Studies. Eligibility for each type of award varies, and is listed on their Prizes and Fellowships website. Upon arrival, graduate students should sign up for the CEAS weekly events e-newsletter.  This will keep you up to date on events about China, Japan, and Korea all over campus. </span></li>
	<li><span><a href="http://fsi.stanford.edu/fellowships/">Freeman Spogli Institute for International Studies (FSI)</a>: FSI provides support to faculty, students, and researchers for academic activies aimed at building student and instructor skills and capacity in the field of international studies. Please review the FSI website for more information regarding fudning types, eligibility, proposal guidelines, and deadlines.</span></li>
	<li><span><a href="https://bechtel.stanford.edu/overseas-scholarships">The Overseas Resource Center at Bechtel International Center (ORC):</a> ORC provides advising for undergraduates, graduate students, postdocs and recent alums pursuing scholarships for study and research abroad. Over 30 scholarships are administered through this office and include such awards as the Fulbright, Marshall, Rhodes, and Churchill. The Center offers one-on-one and group advising sessions and provides support in all aspects of the application process, including interview preparation. In addition to their advising services, the ORC maintains a library of scholarship literature, binders of successful application essays, and for some of our awards, a mentor database of previous Stanford scholars. There are also regular information sessions and application workshops.</span></li>
	<li><span><a href="http://shc.stanford.edu/fellowships">Fellowships through the Stanford Humanities Center (SHC):</a> Each year SHC offers residential fellowships to as many as thirty fellows. These fellows meet regularly in formal and informal sessions while pursuing their individual study, research, and writing. The Center constitutes an intellectual and social community in which historians, philosophers, scholars of literature and the arts, anthropologists, and other humanists of diverse ages, academic ranks, and departmental and institutional affiliations contribute to and learn from one another's work.</span></li>
	<li><span><a href="http://financialaid.stanford.edu/grad/funding/emergency.html">Stanford Financial Aid Office:</a> The financial aid office has limited funds available to help graduate students dealing with difficult financial situations, and provide grants such as:</span>
		<ul><li>Graduate Student Aid Fund: established to assist a limited number of graduate students with University fees such as the Campus Health Service Fee and Cardinal Care Insurance when those fees cause a significant hardship. Students who demonstrate need will be eligible for small amounts to cover specific charges.</li>
			<li>Emergency Grant-In-Aid Funds: Emergency Grant-in-Aid Funds assist graduate students who experience a financial emergency or unanticipated expenses (e.g., medical or dental) causing financial hardship. This program is designed to assist those who cannot reasonably resolve their financial difficulty through fellowships or loans.</li>
			<li>Graduate Housing Loan: Graduate and professional students may apply for loan funds from the University to help with move-in costs for off-campus housing, such as first and last month's rent and security deposit.</li>
		</ul></li>
</ul><h2>Outside Resources</h2>
<ul><li>ACLS Fellowships</li>
	<li>Association for Asian Studies Grants and Fellowships</li>
	<li>National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH) Grants</li>
	<li>Social Science Research Council (SSRC) Fellowships and Grants</li>
	<li>Thomas R. Pickering Foreign Affairs Fellowship</li>
	<li>Academy Scholars Program, the Harvard Academy, Weatherhead Center</li>
	<li>American Association of University Women (AAUW) American Fellowship</li>
	<li>Blakemore Freeman Fellowships and Refresher Grants</li>
	<li>Charlotte W. Newcome Doctoral Dissertation Fellowship</li>
	<li>U.C. Berkeley Center for Chinese Studies Postdoctoral Fellowships in Chinese Studies</li>
	<li>Mellon Fellowships for Dissertation Research in Original Sources</li>
	<li>Woodrow Wilson Doctoral Dissertation Fellowship in Women's Studies</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>

<div id="block-bean-jumpstart-undergraduate-in-the-s" class="clearfix block block-bean well">     <h2>Why study Asia?</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="entity entity-bean bean-stanford-postcard clearfix" about="/block/jumpstart-undergraduate-in-the-s" typeof="">

  <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard"><div class="field-collection-container clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-info field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-4-col-header field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/258" typeof="">
  <div class="content">
    <div class="border-simple-nowidth border-shadow"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/4-col-header/public/2013-07-07_18.12.15.jpg?itok=9gZMREKV" width="370" height="140" alt="" /></div></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-field-s-postcard-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span>“I graduated from Stanford with a degree in Japanese ... I left to teach high school in Japan for a couple of years. It was a great experience: I solidified my language skills, gained some perspective on employment and life in Japan, and made lifelong friends. The linguistic and cultural understanding I gained at Stanford (and during my time in Japan) continues to enrich my life on a daily basis.”</span></p>
<p><span>-- Mike Massey '[year?]</span></p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
 </div>
</div>
</div>
 <!-- /.region -->
</div>
        </div>
        <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Undergraduate Program Overview </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-151" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/undergraduate-program-overview" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Undergraduate Program Overview" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><h2>Bachelor of Arts Degrees</h2>
<p>The Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures Bachelor of Arts degrees in:</p>
<ul><li>Chinese</li>
	<li>Japanese</li>
	<li>East Asian Studies</li>
</ul><p>Required courses and pre-requisites must be completed with a grade point average (GPA) of 2.0 or better.</p>
<h2>Bachelor of Arts Degrees, Honors Programs</h2>
<p>Students majoring in Chinese, Japanese, or East Asian Studies with an overall GPA of 3.5 or higher may apply for the honors program honors program by submitting a senior thesis proposal to the honors committee during Winter or Spring Quarter of the junior year. If approved, research begins the Spring Quarter of the junior year, or by Autumn Quarter of the senior year at the latest. In Winter Quarter of the senior year, students enroll in independent study with the thesis supervisor while writing the thesis, and the finished essay (normally about 15,000 words) is submitted to the committee no later than April 15 of the senior year. For more information, <a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/honors-program">please review the Honors Program requirements.</a></p>
<h2>Bachelor of Arts Degrees, Minor Programs</h2>
<p>The minor in Asian Languages (Chinese, Japanese or East Asian Studies) is also available. These have been designed to give students majoring in other departments an opportunity to gain substantial introduction to Chinese (Mandarin) or Japanese language, as well as an introduction to the culture and civilization of East Asia.</p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

        </div>

  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Undergraduate Program</h2>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Honors Program - Application &amp; Requirements </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-63" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/honors-program-application-requirements" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Honors Program - Application &amp; Requirements" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><h2>Honors Program - Applications and Requirements for all undergraduate major programs</h2>
<p>Majors with an overall grade point average (GPA) of 3.5 may apply for the honors program by submitting a senior thesis proposal to the honors committee during Winter or Spring Quarter of the junior year. The proposal must include the following:</p>
<ul><li>a thesis outline;</li>
	<li>a list of all relevant courses the student has taken or plans to take;</li>
	<li>a preliminary reading list including a work or works in Chinese; and</li>
	<li>the name of a faculty member who has agreed to act as honors supervisor.</li>
</ul><p>If the proposal is approved, research begins in Spring Quarter of the junior year, or by Autumn Quarter of the senior year at the latest, when the student enrolls in <i>CHINA 198H: Senior Research (Honors Thesis)</i> <span>with their faculty adviser</span>. In Winter Quarter, students enroll in five units of independent study (<i>CHINA 198H: Senior Research (Honors Thesis)</i>) with the thesis supervisor while writing the thesis, and the finished essay (normally about 15,000 words) is submitted to the committee no later than April 15th of the senior year. Students enroll in <i>EALC 198: Senior Colloquium</i> in the senior year to polish and present their theses (instead of writing a capstone essay). Eight to eleven units of credit are granted for honors course work and the finished thesis.</p>
<h2>Honors Program in Japanese</h2>
<p>Majors with an overall grade point average (GPA) of 3.5 may apply for the honors program by submitting a senior thesis proposal to the honors committee during Winter or Spring Quarter of the junior year. The proposal must include the following:</p>
<ul><li>a thesis outline;</li>
	<li>a list of all relevant courses the student has taken or plans to take;</li>
	<li>a preliminary reading list including a work or works in Japanese; and</li>
	<li>the name of a faculty member who has agreed to act as honors supervisor.</li>
</ul><p>If the proposal is approved, research begins in Spring Quarter of the junior year, or by Autumn Quarter of the senior year at the latest, when the student enrolls in <strong><em>JAPAN 198H: Senior Research (Honors Thesis)</em></strong>. In Winter Quarter of the senior year, students enroll in five units of independent study <strong><em>JAPAN 198H: Senior Research (Honors Thesis)</em></strong> with the thesis supervisor while writing the thesis, and the finished essay (normally about 15,000 words) is submitted to the committee no later than April 15th of the senior year. Students enroll in <i>EALC 198: Senior Colloquium</i> in the senior year to polish and present their theses. Eight to eleven units of credit are granted for honors course work and the finished thesis.</p>
<h2>Honors Program in East Asian Studies</h2>
<p>Majors with a grade point average (GPA) of 3.5 or better in all courses related to East Asia may apply for the honors program by submitting a senior thesis proposal to the honors committee during Winter or Spring Quarter of the junior year. The proposal must include:</p>
<ul><li>a thesis outline,</li>
	<li>a list of all relevant courses the student has taken or plans to take,</li>
	<li>a preliminary reading list including a work or works in Chinese or Japanese, and</li>
	<li>the name of a faculty member who has agreed to act as honors supervisor.</li>
</ul><p>If the proposal is approved, research begins in Spring Quarter of the junior year, or by Autumn Quarter of the senior year at the latest, when the student enrolls in 2-5 units of independent study. In Winter Quarter, the student enrolls in five units of independent study with the thesis supervisor while writing the thesis, and the finished essay (normally about 15,000 words) is submitted to the committee no later than April 15th of the senior year. Students enroll in CHINGEN 198 (Senior Colloquium in Chinese Studies), JAPANGEN 198 (Senior Colloquium in Japanese Studies), or KORGEN 198 (Senior Colloquium in Korean Studies) in the senior year to polish and present their theses (instead of writing a capstone essay). Eight to eleven units of credit are granted for honors course work and the finished thesis. One advanced level colloquium or seminar dealing with China, Japan, or Korea is required as well.</p>
<h2>Honors Program in East Asian Studies, China Subplan</h2>
<p>Majors with an overall grade point average (GPA) of 3.5 may apply for the honors program by submitting a senior thesis proposal to the honors committee during Winter or Spring Quarter of the junior year. The proposal must include the following: </p>
<ul><li><span>a thesis outline</span></li>
	<li><span>a list of all relevant courses the student has taken or plans to take</span></li>
	<li><span>a preliminary reading list including a work or works in Chinese; and</span></li>
	<li><span>the name of a faculty member who has agreed to act as honors supervisor. </span></li>
</ul><p><span>If the proposal is approved, research begins in Spring Quarter of the junior year, or by Autumn Quarter of the senior year at the latest, when the student enrolls in <i>CHINA 198H: Senior Research (Honors Thesis)</i> with their faculty adviser. In Winter Quarter, students enroll in five units of independent study (</span><i>CHINA 198H: Senior Research (Honors Thesis)</i><span>) with the thesis supervisor again while writing the thesis, and the finished essay (normally about 15,000 words) is submitted to the committee no later than April 15th of the senior year. Students enroll in<i> EALC 198: Senior Colloquium</i> in the senior year to polish and present their theses (instead of writing a capstone essay). Eight to eleven units of credit are granted for honors course work and the finished thesis.</span></p>
<h2>Honors Program in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan</h2>
<p>Majors with an overall grade point average (GPA) of 3.5 may apply for the honors program by submitting a senior thesis proposal to the honors committee during Winter or Spring Quarter of the junior year. The proposal must include the following: </p>
<ul><li>a thesis outline; </li>
	<li>a list of all relevant courses the student has taken or plans to take; </li>
	<li>a preliminary reading list including a work or works in Japanese; and </li>
	<li>the name of a faculty member who has agreed to act as honors supervisor. </li>
</ul><p>If the proposal is approved, research begins in Spring Quarter of the junior year, or by Autumn Quarter of the senior year at the latest, when the student enrolls in <strong><em>JAPAN 198H: Senior Research (Honors Thesis)</em></strong>. In Winter Quarter of the senior year, students enroll in five units of independent study <strong><em>JAPAN 198H: Senior Research (Honors Thesis)</em></strong> with the thesis supervisor while writing the thesis, and the finished essay (normally about 15,000 words) is submitted to the committee no later than April 15th of the senior year. Students enroll in <i>EALC 198: Senior Colloquium</i> in the senior year to polish and present their theses. Eight to eleven units of credit are granted for honors course work and the finished thesis.</p>
<div>
	<h2>Honors Program in East Asian Studies, Korean Subplan</h2>
	<p>Majors with an overall grade point average (GPA) of 3.5 may apply for the honors program by submitting a senior thesis proposal to the honors committee during Winter or Spring Quarter of the junior year. The proposal must include the following: </p>
	<ul><li>a thesis outline; </li>
		<li>a list of all relevant courses the student has taken or plans to take; </li>
		<li>a preliminary reading list including a work or works in Japanese; and </li>
		<li>the name of a faculty member who has agreed to act as honors supervisor. </li>
	</ul><p>If the proposal is approved, research begins in Spring Quarter of the junior year, or by Autumn Quarter of the senior year at the latest, when the student enrolls in <strong><em>KOREA 198H: Senior Research (Honors Thesis)</em></strong>. In Winter Quarter of the senior year, students enroll in five units of independent study <strong><em>KOREA 198H: Senior Research (Honors Thesis)</em></strong> with the thesis supervisor again while writing the thesis, and the finished essay (normally about 15,000 words) is submitted to the committee no later than April 15th of the senior year. Students enroll in <i>EALC 198: Senior Colloquium</i> in the senior year to polish and present their theses. Eight to eleven units of credit are granted for honors course work and the finished thesis.</p>
</div>
<p> </p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>

  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Undergraduate Program</h2>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Honors Program - Application &amp; Requirements </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-63" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/honors-program-application-requirements" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Honors Program - Application &amp; Requirements" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><h2>Honors Program - Applications and Requirements for all undergraduate major programs</h2>
<p>Majors with an overall grade point average (GPA) of 3.5 may apply for the honors program by submitting a senior thesis proposal to the honors committee during Winter or Spring Quarter of the junior year. The proposal must include the following:</p>
<ul><li>a thesis outline;</li>
	<li>a list of all relevant courses the student has taken or plans to take;</li>
	<li>a preliminary reading list including a work or works in Chinese; and</li>
	<li>the name of a faculty member who has agreed to act as honors supervisor.</li>
</ul><p>If the proposal is approved, research begins in Spring Quarter of the junior year, or by Autumn Quarter of the senior year at the latest, when the student enrolls in <i>CHINA 198H: Senior Research (Honors Thesis)</i> <span>with their faculty adviser</span>. In Winter Quarter, students enroll in five units of independent study (<i>CHINA 198H: Senior Research (Honors Thesis)</i>) with the thesis supervisor while writing the thesis, and the finished essay (normally about 15,000 words) is submitted to the committee no later than April 15th of the senior year. Students enroll in <i>EALC 198: Senior Colloquium</i> in the senior year to polish and present their theses (instead of writing a capstone essay). Eight to eleven units of credit are granted for honors course work and the finished thesis.</p>
<h2>Honors Program in Japanese</h2>
<p>Majors with an overall grade point average (GPA) of 3.5 may apply for the honors program by submitting a senior thesis proposal to the honors committee during Winter or Spring Quarter of the junior year. The proposal must include the following:</p>
<ul><li>a thesis outline;</li>
	<li>a list of all relevant courses the student has taken or plans to take;</li>
	<li>a preliminary reading list including a work or works in Japanese; and</li>
	<li>the name of a faculty member who has agreed to act as honors supervisor.</li>
</ul><p>If the proposal is approved, research begins in Spring Quarter of the junior year, or by Autumn Quarter of the senior year at the latest, when the student enrolls in <strong><em>JAPAN 198H: Senior Research (Honors Thesis)</em></strong>. In Winter Quarter of the senior year, students enroll in five units of independent study <strong><em>JAPAN 198H: Senior Research (Honors Thesis)</em></strong> with the thesis supervisor while writing the thesis, and the finished essay (normally about 15,000 words) is submitted to the committee no later than April 15th of the senior year. Students enroll in <i>EALC 198: Senior Colloquium</i> in the senior year to polish and present their theses. Eight to eleven units of credit are granted for honors course work and the finished thesis.</p>
<h2>Honors Program in East Asian Studies</h2>
<p>Majors with a grade point average (GPA) of 3.5 or better in all courses related to East Asia may apply for the honors program by submitting a senior thesis proposal to the honors committee during Winter or Spring Quarter of the junior year. The proposal must include:</p>
<ul><li>a thesis outline,</li>
	<li>a list of all relevant courses the student has taken or plans to take,</li>
	<li>a preliminary reading list including a work or works in Chinese or Japanese, and</li>
	<li>the name of a faculty member who has agreed to act as honors supervisor.</li>
</ul><p>If the proposal is approved, research begins in Spring Quarter of the junior year, or by Autumn Quarter of the senior year at the latest, when the student enrolls in 2-5 units of independent study. In Winter Quarter, the student enrolls in five units of independent study with the thesis supervisor while writing the thesis, and the finished essay (normally about 15,000 words) is submitted to the committee no later than April 15th of the senior year. Students enroll in CHINGEN 198 (Senior Colloquium in Chinese Studies), JAPANGEN 198 (Senior Colloquium in Japanese Studies), or KORGEN 198 (Senior Colloquium in Korean Studies) in the senior year to polish and present their theses (instead of writing a capstone essay). Eight to eleven units of credit are granted for honors course work and the finished thesis. One advanced level colloquium or seminar dealing with China, Japan, or Korea is required as well.</p>
<h2>Honors Program in East Asian Studies, China Subplan</h2>
<p>Majors with an overall grade point average (GPA) of 3.5 may apply for the honors program by submitting a senior thesis proposal to the honors committee during Winter or Spring Quarter of the junior year. The proposal must include the following: </p>
<ul><li><span>a thesis outline</span></li>
	<li><span>a list of all relevant courses the student has taken or plans to take</span></li>
	<li><span>a preliminary reading list including a work or works in Chinese; and</span></li>
	<li><span>the name of a faculty member who has agreed to act as honors supervisor. </span></li>
</ul><p><span>If the proposal is approved, research begins in Spring Quarter of the junior year, or by Autumn Quarter of the senior year at the latest, when the student enrolls in <i>CHINA 198H: Senior Research (Honors Thesis)</i> with their faculty adviser. In Winter Quarter, students enroll in five units of independent study (</span><i>CHINA 198H: Senior Research (Honors Thesis)</i><span>) with the thesis supervisor again while writing the thesis, and the finished essay (normally about 15,000 words) is submitted to the committee no later than April 15th of the senior year. Students enroll in<i> EALC 198: Senior Colloquium</i> in the senior year to polish and present their theses (instead of writing a capstone essay). Eight to eleven units of credit are granted for honors course work and the finished thesis.</span></p>
<h2>Honors Program in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan</h2>
<p>Majors with an overall grade point average (GPA) of 3.5 may apply for the honors program by submitting a senior thesis proposal to the honors committee during Winter or Spring Quarter of the junior year. The proposal must include the following: </p>
<ul><li>a thesis outline; </li>
	<li>a list of all relevant courses the student has taken or plans to take; </li>
	<li>a preliminary reading list including a work or works in Japanese; and </li>
	<li>the name of a faculty member who has agreed to act as honors supervisor. </li>
</ul><p>If the proposal is approved, research begins in Spring Quarter of the junior year, or by Autumn Quarter of the senior year at the latest, when the student enrolls in <strong><em>JAPAN 198H: Senior Research (Honors Thesis)</em></strong>. In Winter Quarter of the senior year, students enroll in five units of independent study <strong><em>JAPAN 198H: Senior Research (Honors Thesis)</em></strong> with the thesis supervisor while writing the thesis, and the finished essay (normally about 15,000 words) is submitted to the committee no later than April 15th of the senior year. Students enroll in <i>EALC 198: Senior Colloquium</i> in the senior year to polish and present their theses. Eight to eleven units of credit are granted for honors course work and the finished thesis.</p>
<div>
	<h2>Honors Program in East Asian Studies, Korean Subplan</h2>
	<p>Majors with an overall grade point average (GPA) of 3.5 may apply for the honors program by submitting a senior thesis proposal to the honors committee during Winter or Spring Quarter of the junior year. The proposal must include the following: </p>
	<ul><li>a thesis outline; </li>
		<li>a list of all relevant courses the student has taken or plans to take; </li>
		<li>a preliminary reading list including a work or works in Japanese; and </li>
		<li>the name of a faculty member who has agreed to act as honors supervisor. </li>
	</ul><p>If the proposal is approved, research begins in Spring Quarter of the junior year, or by Autumn Quarter of the senior year at the latest, when the student enrolls in <strong><em>KOREA 198H: Senior Research (Honors Thesis)</em></strong>. In Winter Quarter of the senior year, students enroll in five units of independent study <strong><em>KOREA 198H: Senior Research (Honors Thesis)</em></strong> with the thesis supervisor again while writing the thesis, and the finished essay (normally about 15,000 words) is submitted to the committee no later than April 15th of the senior year. Students enroll in <i>EALC 198: Senior Colloquium</i> in the senior year to polish and present their theses. Eight to eleven units of credit are granted for honors course work and the finished thesis.</p>
</div>
<p> </p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>

Below are some anecdotes from students whom we have heard from after graduation. If you are an alumnus or alumna who majored our minored in one of our undergraduate programs, we would love to hear from you!" />

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Life after B.A. </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-122" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/life-after-ba" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Life after B.A." class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-image group_s_postcard_image"><div class="field-collection-container clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-info field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-large-scaled field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/271" typeof="">
  <div class="content">
    <div class="border-simple-nowidth border-shadow"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-scaled/public/sankeien-gardens-1088419.jpg?itok=g_UDu4au" width="270" height="152" alt="" /></div></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>Having completed their undergraduate level education at Stanford University, our undergrads are equipped with the necessary skills to tackle various interests: some students choose to continue academia and pursue a Master of Arts or doctoral program at other universities, while others prefer to travel and work abroad in East Asia. Below are some anecdotes from students whom we have heard from after graduation. If you are an alumnus or alumna who majored our minored in one of our undergraduate programs, we would love to hear from you! Please email our Student Services Officer (aitran@stanford.edu) to update us.</p>
<ul><li><strong>Lindsay M. Gibbon, Bachelor of Arts in Japanese (Honors), Class of 2006: </strong>As a Stanford freshman, I adored my Japanese class. It was fun to stretch myself intellectually, deciphering kanji and finding creative ways to express myself in spite of my novice vocabulary. Most of all, it was a joy to come to class and spend time with dedicated teachers and inspiring classmates. By the end of the year, I knew I wanted to major in Japanese, but I had some doubts. What if I couldn't get a job with a humanities degree? Fortunately, my Stanford experience helped me find my path in a way that I couldn't have predicted. After graduation, I got a job at the Ehime University School of Medicine, where I spent the next few years teaching English language classes for physicians and medical students. During this time, not only was I able to polish my Japanese skills, but I had the precious chance to become a part of a community on the other side of the world. I spent many evenings chatting with friends around the dinner table -- doctors, secretaries, school teachers, sake brewers, architects, preschool kids, musicians, and housewives. I even joined the local Shitsukawa softball team. It was a fantastic opportunity to connect with all sorts of different people and learn what makes them tick. I didn't realize how valuable this experience would be until I started my internal medicine residency several years later. As a physician, it doesn't matter how much you know if you aren't able to assess where your patient is coming from and explain their condition in a way that they can understand. My experiences in the Stanford Japanese department helped me to develop the communication skills and adaptability that I needed to grow as a physician.</li>
	<li><strong>Karin Larsen, Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies - Japan (Honors), Class of 2011: </strong>When I came to Stanford I was passionately interested in learning more about Japan - the language, culture, and history, and I was able to explore all of these areas through East Asian Studies. In addition to the variety of courses available, I also had the opportunity to study abroad in Kyoto. Additionally, I was able to intern with two different Japanese companies in Tokyo to learn more about the Japanese working environment and develop my business Japanese language skills. These incredible opportunities later lead to my taking a full time position at one of the companies and being able to work in Tokyo immediately after graduation. While I had aimed to go live and work in Japan as an adult from when I was in middle school, it was incredible to finally realize that dream. Not only did I learn a great deal about Japanese working culture and communication methods from my job, I also got to eat delicious food and travel all over Japan and other parts of Asia while doing so. After building up that experience, I moved back to the Bay Area and was able to utilize my Japanese communication skills and cultural knowledge to help that same company with cross-cultural communication in their San Francisco office. Now I am pursuing an MA in Translation and Interpretation in Japanese at the Monterey Institute of International Studies. My hope is to further develop both my Japanese and my cross-cultural communication skills to continue to be a bridge of understanding between Japan and the United States.</li>
	<li><strong>Chieze Okoye, Bachelor of Arts in Computer Science, Class of 2003, and Master of Arts in East Asian Studies - Japan, Class of 2006: </strong>My name is Chieze Okoye (BAS Computer Science, Japanese ‘03, MA East Asian Studies ‘06) and I currently work as a Game Producer at DeNA West, the western subsidiary of DeNA, one of the biggest mobile game makers in Japan. Immediately out of Stanford, I took a job at the US Market Access Center, a business incubator in San Jose for foreign corporations looking to expand into the United States. A major focus of my work at that time was in helping Japanese businesses specifically, leveraging my language and cultural experience as a tool to bridge the gap for those companies looking to enter the US. Eventually, I decided that I wanted to try for something else, and I came across an opportunity at DeNA Global, DeNA’s then headquarters of its western business. I entered as a Customer Acquisition Specialist (buying and managing ads for our games and social network), but as the team was very small at the time, I had to wear many hats, including product-managing games that DeNA was producing -- both original games and ones imported from DeNA in Japan. In that role I was able to use my Japanese experience quite frequently, since there were always meetings with our colleagues in Japan. Eventually DeNA bought the American smartphone game company ngmoco:) and unified all of their “outside of Japan” businesses as DeNA West, which is where I work now. Looking back, it is very clear that my Japanese major played an integral role in my career path up to now -- a path that I am very happy to be working along -- and I am confident that it will continue to play a major part going forward.</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

<div id="footer" class="clearfix footer site-footer">
  <div class="container">
        <div id="footer-content" class="row-fluid footer-content"> <div class="region region-footer clearfix">

1) In the scroll down menus provided, please direct your gift to School of Humanities and Sciences.
2) In the next step, select Dept or Program and specify Asian Languages in the special instruction/designation field below.
You can also mail your contribution to the EALC office. Checks should be made payable to “Stanford University.”
For assistance or more information, please contact:
Connie Chin, Manager, EALC

                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Major Requirements </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-116" class="node node-stanford-landing-page large-landscape clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Major Requirements" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-field-landing-page-item field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden large-landscape-view-mode"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/253" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/chinese"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/quad_0.png?itok=O3iG5hve" width="370" height="275" alt="" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/chinese" title="Chinese">Chinese</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item odd"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/254" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/japanese"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/poppies_1.png?itok=sJO_4qWV" width="370" height="275" alt="" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/japanese" title="Japanese">Japanese</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item even"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/255" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/arialpalmdrive_0.png?itok=DgXnaPgS" width="370" height="275" alt="" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies" title="East Asian Studies">East Asian Studies</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item odd"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/364" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies-china-subplan"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/the-three-gorges-788314.jpg?itok=Vvu59Wov" width="370" height="275" alt="" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="http://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies-china-subplan" title="East Asian Studies, China Subplan">East Asian Studies, China Subplan</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item even"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/365" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies-japan-subplan"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/sankeien-gardens-1088419_0.jpg?itok=GBObdIm0" width="370" height="275" alt="" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="http://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies-japan-subplan" title="East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan">East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item odd"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/366" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies-korea-subplan"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/photo-1446733993804-c62a351c7239.jpg?itok=hlBPUJdd" width="370" height="275" alt="" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="http://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies-korea-subplan" title="East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan">East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Chinese </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-143" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/chinese" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Chinese" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary"><span>As of Academic year 2016-17, we will no longer offer the Bachelor of Arts in Chinese. Students interested in majoring in Chinese studies may instead declare in the Bachelor of of Arts in East Asian Studies, China Subplan. Students who declared his or her major before September 1, 2016, are still "Chinese majors," completing the Requirements for the Bachelor of Arts in Chinese. Students declaring after September 1, 2016 may declare in the Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, China Subplan; the requirements for the "China Subplan" can be found <a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies-china-subplan">here</a>.</span></p>
<h2><span>Requirements for the Bachelor of Arts in Chinese</span></h2>
<ol><li>Gateway course: CHINGEN 91</li>
	<li>Modern Chinese language requirement:
		<ol><li>First-year modern Chinese from among one of the following series: CHINLANG 1, 2, 3 (First-Year Modern Chinese), or CHINLANG 1B, 2B, 3B (First-Year Modern Chinese for Bilingual Students), or CHINLANG 5 (Intensive First-Year Modern Chinese)</li>
			<li>Second-year modern Chinese from among one of the following series: CHINLANG 21, 22, 23 (Second-Year Modern Chinese), or CHINLANG 21B, 22B, 23B (Second-Year Modern Chinese for Bilingual Students), or CHINLANG 25 (Intensive Second-Year Modern Chinese)</li>
			<li>Third-year modern Chinese from among one of the following series: CHINLANG 101,102 103 (Third-Year Modern Chinese) or CHINLANG 101B, 102B, 103B (Third-Year Modern Chinese for Bilingual Students)</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li>Beginning Classical Chinese: one course from among CHINLIT 125, 126, or 127</li>
	<li>CHINGEN 133 (Literature in 20th Century China) is the required Writing in the Major (WIM) course.</li>
	<li>Content Courses:
		<ol><li>Three courses in CHINGEN or CHINLIT at the 100 level, with one in each of the following areas: pre-modern China, modern China, and Chinese lingustics, as approved by the undergraduate adviser</li>
			<li>Five other content courses dealing with China, as approved by the undergraduate adviser.  One of these must be in the History Department.</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li>Capstone Requirement: CHINGEN 198, Senior Colloquium, including the completion of a capstone essay of approximately 7,500 words, written either in a directed reading course or for one of the courses above.</li>
</ol><p>For questions or inquiries regarding the major, please contact the student services officer, Ai Tran (<a href="mailto:aitran@stanford.edu?subject=Chinese%20Major%20Requirements" rel="nofollow">aitran@stanford.edu</a>).</p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->

<meta name="description" content="Majors in East Asian Studies begin or continue the mastery of Chinese, Japanese, or Korean. Within the humanities or social sciences, they may focus on a particular sub-region. For example: Japan; South China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan; or western China and Central Asia; or a substantive issue involving the region as a whole, such as environmental protection, public health, rural development, historiography, cultural expression, or religious beliefs." />

          <div class="row-fluid"><div class="region region-sidebar-first clearfix">
  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Undergraduate Program</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-stanford_jsa_layouts-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">
  <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-993"><a href="/undergraduate-program/undergraduate-program-overview">Overview</a></li>
<li class="expanded active-trail menu-mlid-968 dropdown-submenu"><a href="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements" class="active-trail dropdown-toggle" data-toggle="dropdown" data-target="#">Major Requirements</a><ul class="dropdown-menu"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-984"><a href="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/japanese">Japanese</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-983"><a href="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/chinese">Chinese</a></li>
<li class="leaf active-trail active menu-mlid-985"><a href="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies" class="active-trail active">East Asian Studies</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1182"><a href="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies-china-subplan">East Asian Studies, China Subplan</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1183"><a href="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies-japan-subplan">East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan</a></li>
<li class="last leaf menu-mlid-1184"><a href="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies-korea-subplan">East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan</a></li>
</ul></li>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> East Asian Studies </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-145" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="East Asian Studies" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary">Majors in East Asian Studies begin or continue the mastery of Chinese, Japanese, or Korean. Within the humanities or social sciences, they may focus on a particular sub-region. For example: Japan; South China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan; or western China and Central Asia; or a substantive issue involving the region as a whole, such as environmental protection, public health, rural development, historiography, cultural expression, or religious beliefs. The major seeks to reduce the complexity of a region to intellectually manageable proportions and illuminate the interrelationships among the various facets of a society.</p>
<h2>Requirements for the Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies</h2>
<p>Potential majors must submit a Student Proposal for a Major in East Asian Studies form not later than the end of the first quarter of the junior year. Majors must complete at least 75 units of coursework on China, Japan, and/or Korea in addition to a 1 unit Senior Colloquium. Courses to be credited toward major requirements must be completed with a grade of ‘C’ or better. Course requirements are as follows:</p>
<ol><li><em><strong>Language Requirement:</strong></em> proficiency in Chinese, Japanese, or Korean language at the second-year level or above, to be met either by coursework or examination. Students who meet the requirement through examination are still expected to take an additional 15 units of language at a higher level, or literature courses taught in the language, or the first year in an additional Asian language. No more than 30 units of language courses are counted toward the major.</li>
	<li><em><strong>Area Courses:</strong></em> a minimum of three area courses, one in each category below. (Please note: courses listed are examples and by no means exhaustive. Consult the bulletin or Axess for a more complete list. If uncertain whether a particular course fits into one of these categories, please contact the department to confirm.)
		<ol><li><strong>Humanities</strong>
				<ul><li>CHINA 111: Literature in 20th Century China</li>
					<li>CHINA 153: Chinese Bodies, Chinese Selves</li>
					<li>EALC 198: Senior Colloquium</li>
					<li>JAPAN 124: Manga as Literature</li>
					<li>JAPAN 138: Introduction to Modern Japanese Literature and Culture</li>
					<li>JAPAN 184/ARTHIST 184: Aristocrats, Warriors, Sex Workers, and Barbarians: Lived Life in Early Modern Japanese Painting</li>
					<li>KOREA 101N, Kangnam Style: Korean Media and Pop Culture</li>
					<li>KOREA 121: Doing the Right Thing: Ethical Dilemmas in Korean Film</li>
					<li>RELIGST 50: Exploring Buddhism</li>
					<li>RELIGST 55: Exploring Zen Buddhism</li>
					<li>RELIGST 56: Exploring Chinese Religions</li>
					<li><em>Previously offered courses that still count toward the Humanities requirements</em>: CHINGEN 132: Chinese Fiction and Drama in Translation, CHINGEN 194: The History and Culture of Peking Opera</li>
				</ul></li>
			<li><strong>History</strong>
				<ul><li>HISTORY 11SC: How is a Buddhist</li>
					<li>HISTORY 92A: The Historical Roots of Modern East Asia</li>
					<li>HISTORY 95/195: Modern Korean History</li>
					<li>HISTORY 95C/195C: Modern Japanese History: From Samurai to Pokemon</li>
					<li>HISTORY 106A: Global Human Geography: Asia and Africa</li>
					<li>HISTORY 94B/194B: Japan in the Age of the Samurai</li>
					<li>HISTORY 292F: Culture and Religions in Korean History</li>
					<li>HISTORY 295F: Race and Ethnicity in East Asia</li>
					<li><i>Previously offered courses that still count toward the History requirements:</i> HISTORY 92: Early Empires in China, HISTORY 13: The Historical and Geographical Background of Current Global Events, HISTORY 295J: Chinese Women's History</li>
				</ul></li>
			<li><strong>Social Sciences</strong>
				<ul><li>JAPAN 151: Japanese Business Culture and Systems</li>
					<li>EASTASN 117: Health and Healthcare Systems in East Asia</li>
					<li>LAW 5001: China Law and Business</li>
					<li>IPS 244: U.S. Policy toward Northeast Asia</li>
					<li>IPS 246: China on the World Stage</li>
					<li>POLISCI 148: Chinese Politics</li>
					<li>POLISCI 211P: International Security in South Asia, Pakistan, India and the United States</li>
					<li>SOC 116: Chinese Organizations and Management</li>
					<li>SOC 117A: China Under Mao</li>
					<li>SOC 167A: Asia-Pacific Transformation</li>
					<li><em>Previously offered courses that still count toward the Social Sciences requirements:</em> POLISCI 211: Political Economy of East Asia</li>
				</ul></li>
		</ol></li>
	<li><em><strong>Substantive Concentration: </strong></em>additional courses on East Asia, one of which must be a seminar above the 100 level. Majors are encouraged to distribute their course work among at least three disciplines and two subregions in Asia. The subregions need not be traditionally defined. Examples include China, Japan, or Korea; or, in recognition of the new subregions which are emerging, South China and Taiwan, or Central Asia. At least four courses must have a thematic coherence built around a topic such as:
		<ul><li>East Asian religions and philosophies</li>
			<li>Culture and society of modern Japan</li>
			<li>Ethnic identities in East Asia</li>
			<li>Arts and literature in late imperial China</li>
			<li>Foreign policy in East Asia</li>
			<li>Social transformation of modern Korea</li>
			<li>China’s political economy</li>
		</ul></li>
	<li><em><strong>Capstone Essay: </strong></em>completion of a paper of approximately 7,500 words, written either in a directed reading course or for one of the courses in item 3 above, which should be built upon the student’s thematic interest. EALC 198, taken for 3 units, is required of majors during Winter quarter of the senior year to develop, and to present the capstone essay or honors paper in Spring quarter of the senior year. A faculty adviser for the capstone essay must be submitted by the beginning of Autumn Quarter of the student's senior year.</li>
	<li><em><strong>Overseas Experience:</strong></em> At least one quarter overseas in the country of focus.</li>
	<li><strong><em>Writing in the Major Requirement:</em></strong> An East Asian Studies course that satisfies the University Writing in the Major (WIM) requirement should be completed before beginning the senior essay. CHINA 211: Literaturey in 20th-century China, JAPAN 138: Introduction to Modern Japanese Literature and Culture, and KOREA 120: Narratives of Modern and Contemporary Korea satisfy the WIM requirement.</li>
	<li><strong><em>Total Unit Minimum:</em></strong>The courses for the major must add up to at least 78 units, comprised of the three-unit Senior Colloquium and at least 75 additional units, all taken for a letter grade. Courses must be at least three units to be counted towards the degree.</li>
</ol></div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->

  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Undergraduate Program</h2>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> East Asian Studies, China Subplan </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-434" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies-china-subplan" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="East Asian Studies, China Subplan" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><h2><span>Requirements for the Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, China Subplan</span></h2>
<p>The Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, China Subplan, offers students the ability to study East Asia with a special focus on Chinese culture and language. The Bachelor of Arts The Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, China Subplan, replaced the department's Bachelor of Arts in Chinese. Students currently pursuing the Bachelor of Arts in Chinese may choose to continue his or her plan of study, or opt to complete the Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, China Subplan requirement instead. Note: Once students drop the Bachelor of Arts in Chinese on Axess, they cannot re-enroll/declare under the Bachelor of Arts in Chinese again. Consult Prof. Yiqun Zhou, EALC’s Director of Undergraduate Studies, or Ai Tran, EALC’s student services officer, for more clarification.</p>
<p>The following requirements are are in addition to the University’s basic requirements for the bachelor’s degree. Letter grades are mandatory for required courses.</p>
<p>Courses taken to complete the major requirements as well as their prerequisites must be completed with a grade point average (GPA) of 2.0 or better.</p>
<ol><li>Gateway Courses: Students must take two gateway courses appropriate to the East Asian Studies, China Subplan. Courses can be from the “East Asian Gateway Course Cluster” and/or the “Gateway Course Cluster for the China Subplan." At least one of the two gateway courses chosen must be taught by a member in the EALC department. <a href="https://stanford.box.com/v/EALCGatewayCourses" rel="nofollow">List of Approved Gateway Courses.</a></li>
	<li>Proficiency of the modern Chinese language, at the third year level: Students take a minimum of 3 years of modern Chinese language courses. Students should take a language assessment test offered at the Language Center to determine language proficiency before signing up for classes. </li>
	<li>Beginning classical Chinese: Students must take at least one classical Chinese course.
		<ol><li>CHINA 105: Beginning Classical Chinese, First Quarter</li>
			<li>CHINA 106: Beginning Classical Chinese, Second Quarter</li>
			<li>CHINA 107: Beginning Classical Chinese, Third Quarter</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li>Additional courses: Students must take additional content courses to fulfill the requirement. The following courses selected should be discussed with the Director of Undergraduate Studies for approval.
		<ol><li>Three CHINA courses at the 100 level with one in each of the following areas: pre-modern China, modern China, and Chinese linguistics.</li>
			<li>Four other content courses, as approved by the undergraduate faculty adviser. One of these should be a History course offered by the Department of History.</li>
			<li>All students take <em><strong>CHINA 111: Literature in 20-th Century China</strong></em> as part of the Writing in the Major (WIM) requirement.</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li><strong>Capstone requirement:</strong> Students enroll in <em><strong>EALC 198: Senior Colloquium</strong></em> winter quarter of the senior year with other seniors to complete the Senior Capstone Essay or Honors Thesis. A capstone essay is approximately 7,500 words, and the honors thesis approximately 15,000.</li>
</ol><p>For questions or inquiries regarding the major, please contact our department student services officer, Ai Tran (<a href="mailto:aitran@stanford.edu?subject=Chinese%20Major%20Requirements" rel="nofollow">aitran@stanford.edu</a>).</p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-435" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies-japan-subplan" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><h2><span>Requirements for the Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan</span></h2>
<p>The Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan, offers students the ability to study East Asia with a special focus on Japanese culture and language. The Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan, replaced the department's Bachelor of Arts in Japanese. Students currently pursuing the Bachelor of Arts in Japanese may choose to continue his or her plan of study, or opt to complete the Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan requirement instead. Note: Once students drop the Bachelor of Arts in Japanese on Axess, he or she cannot re-enroll/declare under the Bachelor of Arts in Japanese again. Consult Prof. Yiqun Zhou, Director of Undergraduate Studies, or Ai Tran, EALC’s student services officer, for more clarification.</p>
<p>The following requirements are are in addition to the University’s basic requirements for the bachelor’s degree. Letter grades are mandatory for required courses.</p>
<p>Courses taken to complete the major requirements as well as their prerequisites must be completed with a grade point average (GPA) of 2.0 or better.</p>
<ol><li>Gateway courses: Students must take two gateway courses appropriate to the East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan. Courses can be from the “East Asian Gateway Course Cluster” and/or the “Gateway Course Cluster for the Japan Subplan." At least one of the two gateway courses chosen must be taught by a member in the EALC department. <a href="https://stanford.box.com/v/EALCGatewayCourses" rel="nofollow">List of Approved Gateway Courses.</a></li>
	<li>Proficiency of the modern Japanese language, at the third year level: Students take a minimum of 3 years of modern Japanese language courses. Students should take a language assessment test offered at the Language Center to determine language proficiency before signing up for classes.</li>
	<li>Additional courses: Students must take additional content courses to fulfill the requirement. The following courses selected should be discussed with the Director of Undergraduate Studies for approval.
		<ol><li>Three JAPAN courses at the 100-level with one in each of the following areas: pre-modern Japan, modern Japan, and Japanese linguistics.</li>
			<li>Four other content courses dealin with Japan primarily at the 100-level.</li>
			<li>Amongst the list of "Additional courses," all students must take <em><strong>JAPAN 138: Introduction to Modern Japanese Literature and Culture</strong></em>, our Writing in the Major (WIM) course</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li><strong>Capstone Requirement:</strong> Students enroll in <em><strong>EALC 198: Senior Colloquium</strong></em> winter quarter of the senior year with other seniors to complete the Senior Capstone Essay or Honors Thesis. A capstone essay is approximately 7,500 words, and the honors thesis approximately 15,000.</li>
</ol><p>For questions or inquiries regarding the major, please contact our department student services officer, Ai Tran (<a href="mailto:aitran@stanford.edu?subject=Chinese%20Major%20Requirements" rel="nofollow">aitran@stanford.edu</a>).</p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-436" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies-korea-subplan" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><h2><span>Requirements for the Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan</span></h2>
<p>The Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan, offers students the ability to study East Asia with a special focus on Korean culture and language. The following requirements are in addtion to the University's basic requiremenets for the bachelor's degree. Students must take all courses for a letter grade, and the courses as well as their prerequisites must be completed with a grade point average (GPA) of 2.0 or better.</p>
<ol><li>Gateway courses: Students must take two gateway courses appropriate to the East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan. Courses can be from the “East Asian Gateway Course Cluster” and/or the “Gateway Course Cluster for the Korea Subplan." At least one of the two gateway courses chosen must be taught by a member in the EALC department. <a href="https://stanford.box.com/v/EALCGatewayCourses" rel="nofollow">List of Approved Gateway Courses.</a></li>
	<li>Proficiency of the modern Korean language, at the third year level: Students take a minimum of 3 years of modern Korean language courses. Students should take a language assessment test offered at the Language Center to determine language proficiency before signing up for classes.</li>
	<li>Additional courses: Students must take additional content courses to fulfill the requirement. The following courses selected should be discussed with the Director of Undergraduate Studies for approval.
		<ol><li>Take 6 KOREA courses at the 100-level, a minimum of two 100-level courses must be offered by the department.</li>
			<li>Amongst the list of "Additional courses," all students must take <em><strong>KOREA 120: Narratives of Modern and Contemporary Korea</strong></em>, our Writing in the Major (WIM) course</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li><strong>Capstone Requirement:</strong> Students enroll in <em><strong>EALC 198: Senior Colloquium</strong></em> winter quarter of the senior year with other seniors to complete the Senior Capstone Essay or Honors Thesis. A capstone essay is approximately 7,500 words, and the honors thesis approximately 15,000.</li>
</ol><p>For questions or inquiries regarding the major, please contact our department student services officer, Ai Tran (<a href="mailto:aitran@stanford.edu?subject=Chinese%20Major%20Requirements" rel="nofollow">aitran@stanford.edu</a>).</p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->

<div id="block-bean-jumpstart-footer-social-media-0" class="clearfix block block-bean span2">     <h2>Connect</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="entity entity-bean bean-stanford-social-media-connect clearfix" about="/block/jumpstart-footer-social-media--0" typeof="">

  <div class="content">

Students interested in majoring in Japanese studies may instead declare in the Bachelor of of Arts in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan. Students who declared his or her major before September 1, 2016, are still &quot;Japanese majors,&quot; completing the Requirements for the Bachelor of Arts in Japanese (see below)." />
