                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Japanese </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-144" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/japanese" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Japanese" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary"><span>As of Academic year 2016-17, we will no longer offer the Bachelor of Arts in Japanese. Students interested in majoring in Japanese studies may instead declare in the Bachelor of of Arts in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan. Students who declared his or her major before September 1, 2016, are still "Japanese majors," completing the Requirements for the Bachelor of Arts in Japanese (see below). Students declaring after September 1, 2016 may declare in the Bachelor of Arts in East Asian Studies, China Subplan; the requirements for the "Japan Subplan" can be found <a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/major-requirements/east-asian-studies-japan-subplan">here</a>.</span></p>
<h2>Requirements for the Bachelor of Arts in Japanese</h2>
<ol><li>Gateway course: JAPANGEN 92</li>
	<li>Modern Japanese language requirement:
		<ol><li>JAPANLNG 1, 2, and 3 (First-Year Japanese Language, Culture, and Communication), or JAPANLNG 5 (Intensive First-Year Japanese)</li>
			<li>JAPANLNG 21, 22, and 23 (Second-Year Japanese Language, Culture, and Communication), or JAPANLNG 20 (Intensive Second-Year Japanese)</li>
			<li>JAPANLNG101, 102, and 103 (Third-Year Japanese Language, Culture, and Communication)</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li>JAPANGEN 138 (Introduction to Modern Japanese Literature and Culture), which is the required Writing in the Major (WIM) course</li>
	<li>Content Courses:</li>
	<li>
		<ol><li>Four courses in JAPANGEN or JAPANLIT at the 100 level, with one in each of the following areas as approved by the undergraduate adviser: pre-modern Japan, modern Japan, and Japanese linguistics</li>
			<li>Four other content courses dealing with Japan, primarily at the 100 level, as approved by the undergraduate adviser</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li>JAPANGEN 198, Senior Colloquium in Japanese Studies, including the completion of a capstone essay of approximately 7,500 words, written either in a directed reading course or for one of the content courses above. Must have an adviser for the capstone essay by the beginning of Autumn Quarter, senior year.</li>
</ol><p>Please Note: Students who complete third-year Japanese at KCJS satisfy the language requirement but are required to take a placement test if they wish to enroll in JAPANLNG 211, 212, 213 (Fourth-Year Japanese)</p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

The minor may be designed from the following, for a total of six courses and a minimum of 20 units. All courses should be taken for a letter grade." />

          <div class="row-fluid"><div class="region region-sidebar-first clearfix">
  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Undergraduate Program</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-stanford_jsa_layouts-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">
  <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-993"><a href="/undergraduate-program/undergraduate-program-overview">Overview</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-968"><a href="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements">Major Requirements</a></li>
<li class="expanded active-trail menu-mlid-969 dropdown-submenu"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor-requirements" class="active-trail dropdown-toggle" data-toggle="dropdown" data-target="#">Minor Requirements</a><ul class="dropdown-menu"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-986"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-chinese">Minor in Chinese</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-987"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-japanese">Minor in Japanese</a></li>
<li class="leaf active-trail active menu-mlid-1179"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor-requirement/minor-east-asian-studies" class="active-trail active">Minor in East Asian Studies</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1185"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-east-asian-studies-china-subplan">Minor in East Asian Studies, China Subplan</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1186"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-east-asian-studies-japan-subplan">Minor in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1187"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor-requirements/minor-east-asian-studies-korea-subplan">Minor in East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan</a></li>

        <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Minor in East Asian Studies </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-381" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/minor-requirement/minor-east-asian-studies" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Minor in East Asian Studies" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>The goal of the minor in East Asian Studies is to provide the student with a broad background in East Asian culture as a whole, while allowing the student to focus on a geographical or temporal aspect of East Asia. The minor may be designed from the following, for a total of six courses and a minimum of 20 units. All courses should be taken for a letter grade.</p>
<h2>East Asian Studies Minor Requirements</h2>
<ol><li>Three area courses, one in each category (see East Asian Studies List of Area Courses, see below).</li>
	<li>One undergraduate seminar above the 100 level and two other courses from among those listed as approved for East Asian Studies majors, including literature courses but excluding language courses. These courses are listed under the East Asian Studies major in this bulletin.</li>
</ol><p>Applications for the minor should be submitted online through Axess and are due no later than the second quarter of the junior year.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>East Asian Studies List of Area Courses</strong></p>
<p><strong>Humanities</strong></p>
<ul><li>CHINGEN 132, Chinese Fiction and Drama in Translation</li>
	<li>CHINGEN 133, Literature in 20th Century China</li>
	<li>CHINGEN 135, Chinese Bodies, Chinese Selves</li>
	<li>CHINGEN 194, The History and Culture of Peking Opera</li>
	<li>CHINGEN 198, Senior Colloquium in Chinese Studies</li>
	<li>JAPANGEN 124, Manga as Literature</li>
	<li>JAPANGEN 138, Introduction to Modern Japanese Literature and Culture</li>
	<li>JAPANGEN 184, Aristocrats, Warriors, Sex Workers, and Barbarians: Lived Life in Early Modern Japanese Painting</li>
	<li>KORGEN 101N, Kangnam Style: Korean Media and Pop Culture</li>
	<li>KORGEN 121, Doing the Right Thing: Ethical Dilemmas in Korean Film</li>
	<li>RELIGST 50, Exploring Buddhism</li>
	<li>RELIGST 55. Exploring Zen</li>
	<li>RELIGST 56, Exploring Chinese Religions</li>
</ul><p><strong>History</strong></p>
<ul><li>HISTORY 92. Early Empires in China </li>
	<li>HISTORY 11SC, How is a Buddhist </li>
	<li>HISTORY 13, The Historical and Geographical Background of Current Global Events </li>
	<li>HISTORY 92A, The Historical Roots of Modern East Asia </li>
	<li>HISTORY 95/195, Modern Korean History </li>
	<li>HISTORY 95C/195C, Modern Japanese History: From Samurai to Pokemon </li>
	<li>HISTORY 106A, Global Human Geography: Asia and Africa </li>
	<li>HISTORY 194B, Japan in the Age of the Samurai </li>
	<li>HISTORY 292F, Culture and Religions in Korean History </li>
	<li>HISTORY 295J, Chinese Women's History</li>
</ul><p><strong>Social Sciences </strong></p>
<ul><li>JAPANGEN 51, Japanese Business Culture and Systems </li>
	<li>EASTASN 217, Health and Healthcare Systems in East Asia </li>
	<li>LAW 245, China Law and Business </li>
	<li>IPS 244, U.S. Policy toward Northeast Asia </li>
	<li>IPS 246, China on the World Stage </li>
	<li>POLISCI 148, Chinese Politics: The Transformation and the Era of Reform </li>
	<li>POLISCI 211, Political Economy of East Asia </li>
	<li>SOC 116, Chinese Organizations and Management </li>
	<li>SOC 117A, China Under Mao </li>
	<li>SOC 167A, Asia-Pacific Transformation</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->

          <div class="row-fluid"><div class="region region-sidebar-first clearfix">
  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Undergraduate Program</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-stanford_jsa_layouts-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">
  <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-993"><a href="/undergraduate-program/undergraduate-program-overview">Overview</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-968"><a href="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements">Major Requirements</a></li>
<li class="expanded active-trail active menu-mlid-969 dropdown-submenu"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor-requirements" class="active-trail dropdown-toggle active" data-toggle="dropdown" data-target="#">Minor Requirements</a><ul class="dropdown-menu"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-986"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-chinese">Minor in Chinese</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-987"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-japanese">Minor in Japanese</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1179"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor-requirement/minor-east-asian-studies">Minor in East Asian Studies</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1185"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-east-asian-studies-china-subplan">Minor in East Asian Studies, China Subplan</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1186"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-east-asian-studies-japan-subplan">Minor in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1187"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor-requirements/minor-east-asian-studies-korea-subplan">Minor in East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan</a></li>
<li class="last leaf menu-mlid-1188"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-translation-studies">Minor in Translation Studies</a></li>
</ul></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-612"><a href="/undergraduate-program/honors-program-application-requirements">Honors Program - Applications and Requirements</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-971"><a href="/undergraduate-program/research-opportunities">Research Opportunities</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-972"><a href="/undergraduate-program/study-abroad">Study Abroad</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-973"><a href="/undergraduate-program/undergraduate-awards">Undergraduate Awards</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-974"><a href="/undergraduate-program/life-after-ba">Life after B.A.</a></li>
<li class="last leaf menu-mlid-975"><a href="/undergraduate-program/prospective-undergrads">Prospective Undergrads</a></li>
</ul></div>
 </div>

        </div>
        <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Minor Requirements </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-117" class="node node-stanford-landing-page large-landscape clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/minor-requirements" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Minor Requirements" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p><span>The Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures offers minor degrees in the following:</span></p>
<ul><li><span>Chinese (no longer offered as of September 1, 2016)</span></li>
	<li><span>Japanese </span> (no longer offered as of September 1, 2016)</li>
	<li><span>East Asian Studies</span></li>
	<li><span>East Asian Studies, China Subplan (replaces Chinese minor)</span></li>
	<li>East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan (replaces Japanese minor)</li>
	<li>East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan</li>
</ul><p>The undergraduate minors in Chinese and Japanese have been designed to give students majoring in other departments an opportunity to gain a substantial introduction to Chinese or Japanese language, as well as an introduction to the culture and civilization of East Asia. The minors consist of a minimum of 20 units from the following requirements: One introductory core course, below. Three other departmental courses in the relevant field approved by the adviser, and language requirement as listed below.</p>
<p>The goal of the minor in East Asian Studies is to provide the student with a broad background in East Asian culture as a whole, while allowing the student to focus on a geographical or temporal aspect of East Asia. The minor may be designed from the following, for a total of six courses and a minimum of 20 units. All courses should be taken for a letter grade.</p>
<p>The Division of Literatures, Cultures, and Languages offers a "Minor in Translation Studies" which may be of interest to students in East Asian Languages and Cultures. The DLCL, in cooperation with EALC and the English Department, teaches undergraduates to develop and apply their foreign language knowledge to the production and analysis of translations. The minor is designed to give students majoring in a variety of fields the tools to consider the practical and theoretical issues brought up by translation as an aesthetic, cultural, and ethical practice. <a href="http://exploredegrees.stanford.edu/schoolofhumanitiesandsciences/divisionofliteraturesculturesandlanguages/#minortext">Click here for more information on the "Minor in Translation Studies."</a></p>
</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-landing-page-item field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden large-landscape-view-mode"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/256" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/minor/chinese"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/quad_memorial_church2_0.png?itok=-MLL4zpV" width="370" height="275" alt="" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/minor/chinese" title="Chinese">Chinese</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item odd"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/257" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/minor/japanese"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/quad_bikes_people_0.png?itok=UlmVxh1q" width="370" height="275" alt="" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/minor/japanese" title="Japanese">Japanese</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item even"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/367" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-east-asian-studies"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/photo-1468327768560-75b778cbb551.jpg?itok=c5CXRwoH" width="370" height="275" alt="" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-east-asian-studies" title="East Asian Studies">East Asian Studies</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item odd"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/368" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-east-asian-studies-china-subplan"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/photo-1467363469209-43012e2fa1f7.jpg?itok=TgA_bbLi" width="370" height="275" alt="" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-east-asian-studies-china-subplan" title="East Asian Studies, China Subplan">East Asian Studies, China Subplan</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item even"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/369" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-east-asian-studies-japan-subplan"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/photo-1472360666101-23369f0128f1.jpg?itok=7mgC4LKI" width="370" height="275" alt="" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-east-asian-studies-japan-subplan" title="East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan">East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

</div><div class="field-item odd"><div  about="/field-collection/field-landing-page-item/370" typeof="" class="ds-1col entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-landing-page-item view-mode-large_landscape clearfix">

  
  <div class="tile"><div class="tile-link column"><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-east-asian-studies-korea-subplan"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-landscape/public/photo-1467810921751-3d4592582a05.jpg?itok=nS9nAO9x" width="370" height="275" alt="" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-lp-item-title field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-east-asian-studies-korea-subplan" title="East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan">East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan</a></h2></div></div></div></div></div></div>

<meta name="description" content="As of September 1, 2016, the Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures will offer a new undergraduate program: the minor in East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan. The &quot;Korea Subplan&quot; minor has been designed to give students majoring in other departments an opportunity to gain a substantial introduction to the Korean language, as well as an introduction to the culture and civilization of East Asia." />

          <div class="row-fluid"><div class="region region-sidebar-first clearfix">
  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Undergraduate Program</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-stanford_jsa_layouts-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">
  <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-993"><a href="/undergraduate-program/undergraduate-program-overview">Overview</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-968"><a href="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements">Major Requirements</a></li>
<li class="expanded active-trail menu-mlid-969 dropdown-submenu"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor-requirements" class="active-trail dropdown-toggle" data-toggle="dropdown" data-target="#">Minor Requirements</a><ul class="dropdown-menu"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-986"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-chinese">Minor in Chinese</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-987"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-japanese">Minor in Japanese</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1179"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor-requirement/minor-east-asian-studies">Minor in East Asian Studies</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1185"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-east-asian-studies-china-subplan">Minor in East Asian Studies, China Subplan</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1186"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-east-asian-studies-japan-subplan">Minor in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan</a></li>
<li class="leaf active-trail active menu-mlid-1187"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor-requirements/minor-east-asian-studies-korea-subplan" class="active-trail active">Minor in East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan</a></li>

</ul></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-612"><a href="/undergraduate-program/honors-program-application-requirements">Honors Program - Applications and Requirements</a></li>

</ul></div>

</div>
        </div>
        <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Minor in East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-439" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/minor-requirements/minor-east-asian-studies-korea-subplan" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Minor in East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary">As of September 1, 2016, the Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures will offer a new undergraduate program: the minor in East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan. The "Korea Subplan" minor has been designed to give students majoring in other departments an opportunity to gain a substantial introduction to the Korean language, as well as an introduction to the culture and civilization of East Asia.</p>
<div>
	<h2>Minor in East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan</h2>
	<p>The minors consist of a minimum of 20 units from the following requirements (see below). All courses for the minor must be taken for a letter grade and completed with a GPA of 2.0 or better. Consult with the department to potentially count one of the BOSP courses taught by a Stanford home campus faculty member toward the minor:</p>
	<ol><li><strong>Proficiency of the modern Korean language, at the second year level: </strong>Students complete two years of modern Korean. Those who already have a competence at the second-year level may fulfill the language component of the minor by taking three courses in the department using materials in Korean. These courses may be language courses such as the third-year sequence mentioned above, the fourth-year language sequence, or they may be advanced literature and linguistics courses, depending on the capabilities and interests of the student.</li>
		<li><strong>Gateway courses:</strong> Complete two gateway courses offered by the EALC department; students make take courses from the “East Asian Gateway Course Cluster” and/or the “Gateway Course Cluster for Korea Subplan." At least one of the two gateway courses chosen must be taught by a member in the EALC department. <a href="https://stanford.box.com/v/EALCGatewayCourses" rel="nofollow">List of Approved Gateway Courses.</a></li>
		<li><strong>Additional content courses:</strong>Three courses selected from among the department's other offerings in the literature, film, and popular culture. Up to one course can be approved from outside the department with the Director of Undergraduate Studies's approval.</li>
	</ol><p>​For questions or inquiries regarding the minor, please contact our department student services officer, Ai Tran (<a href="mailto:aitran@stanford.edu?subject=Chinese%20Major%20Requirements" rel="nofollow">aitran@stanford.edu</a>).</p>
</div>
<p> </p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->

The minors consist of a minimum of 20 units from the following requirements: One introductory core course, below.                 <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Minor in Chinese </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-146" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-chinese" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Minor in Chinese" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>The undergraduate minors in Chinese and Japanese have been designed to give students majoring in other departments an opportunity to gain a substantial introduction to Chinese or Japanese language, as well as an introduction to the culture and civilization of East Asia. The minors consist of a minimum of 20 units from the following requirements: One introductory core course, below. Three other departmental courses in the relevant field approved by the adviser, and language requirement as listed below.</p>
<h2>Chinese Minor Requirements</h2>
<ol><li>Completion of language study through the second-year level for students with no previous training in Chinese. Students who already have first-year competence in Chinese must complete the third-year course. Students who already have a competence at the second-year level may fulfill the language component of the minor by taking three courses in the department using materials in either Chinese or Japanese. These courses may be language courses such as the third-year sequence mentioned above, the fourth-year language sequence, or they may be advanced literature and linguistics courses, depending on the capabilities and interests of the student.</li>
	<li>CHINGEN 91: Introduction to China</li>
	<li>Three courses selected from among the department's other offerings in the literature, linguistics, and civilization of the relevant minor area (CHINGEN, CHINLIT). All courses for the minor must be taken for a letter grade and completed with a GPA of 2.0 or better. Consult with the Undergraduate Studies Adviser to potentially count one of the OSPKYOTO courses taught by a Stanford home campus faculty member toward the minor.</li>
</ol></div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>
                                                                                                                      </div>

<div id="block-bean-jumpstart-footer-social-media-0" class="clearfix block block-bean span2">     <h2>Connect</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="entity entity-bean bean-stanford-social-media-connect clearfix" about="/block/jumpstart-footer-social-media--0" typeof="">

  <div class="content">

<meta name="description" content="The undergraduate minors in Chinese and Japanese have been designed to give students majoring in other departments an opportunity to gain a substantial introduction to Chinese or Japanese language, as well as an introduction to the culture and civilization of East Asia. The minors consist of a minimum of 20 units from the following requirements: One introductory core course, below. Three other departmental courses in the relevant field approved by the adviser, and language requirement as listed below." />

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Minor in Japanese </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-147" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-japanese" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Minor in Japanese" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>The undergraduate minors in Chinese and Japanese have been designed to give students majoring in other departments an opportunity to gain a substantial introduction to Chinese or Japanese language, as well as an introduction to the culture and civilization of East Asia. The minors consist of a minimum of 20 units from the following requirements: One introductory core course, below. Three other departmental courses in the relevant field approved by the adviser, and language requirement as listed below.</p>
<h2>Japanese Minor Requirements</h2>
<ol><li>Completion of language study through the second-year level for students with no previous training in Japanese. Students who already have first-year competence in Japanese must complete the third-year course. Students who already have a competence at the second-year level may fulfill the language component of the minor by taking three courses in the department using materials in either Chinese or Japanese. These courses may be language courses such as the third-year sequence mentioned above, the fourth-year language sequence, or they may be advanced literature and linguistics courses, depending on the capabilities and interests of the student.</li>
	<li>JAPANGEN 92: Introduction to Japan</li>
	<li>Three courses selected from among the department's other offerings in the literature, linguistics, and civilization of the relevant minor area (JAPANGEN, JAPANLIT). All courses for the minor must be taken for a letter grade and completed with a GPA of 2.0 or better. Consult with the Undergraduate Studies Adviser to potentially count one of the OSPKYOTO courses taught by a Stanford home campus faculty member toward the minor.</li>
</ol></div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

<meta name="description" content="The undergraduate minors in Chinese and Japanese have been designed to give students majoring in other departments an opportunity to gain a substantial introduction to Chinese or Japanese language, as well as an introduction to the culture and civilization of East Asia. The minors consist of a minimum of 20 units from the following requirements: One introductory core course, below. Three other departmental courses in the relevant field approved by the adviser, and language requirement as listed below." />

  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Undergraduate Program</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-stanford_jsa_layouts-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Minor in Chinese </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-146" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-chinese" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Minor in Chinese" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>The undergraduate minors in Chinese and Japanese have been designed to give students majoring in other departments an opportunity to gain a substantial introduction to Chinese or Japanese language, as well as an introduction to the culture and civilization of East Asia. The minors consist of a minimum of 20 units from the following requirements: One introductory core course, below. Three other departmental courses in the relevant field approved by the adviser, and language requirement as listed below.</p>
<h2>Chinese Minor Requirements</h2>
<ol><li>Completion of language study through the second-year level for students with no previous training in Chinese. Students who already have first-year competence in Chinese must complete the third-year course. Students who already have a competence at the second-year level may fulfill the language component of the minor by taking three courses in the department using materials in either Chinese or Japanese. These courses may be language courses such as the third-year sequence mentioned above, the fourth-year language sequence, or they may be advanced literature and linguistics courses, depending on the capabilities and interests of the student.</li>
	<li>CHINGEN 91: Introduction to China</li>
	<li>Three courses selected from among the department's other offerings in the literature, linguistics, and civilization of the relevant minor area (CHINGEN, CHINLIT). All courses for the minor must be taken for a letter grade and completed with a GPA of 2.0 or better. Consult with the Undergraduate Studies Adviser to potentially count one of the OSPKYOTO courses taught by a Stanford home campus faculty member toward the minor.</li>
</ol></div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

<meta name="description" content="The goal of the minor in East Asian Studies is to provide the student with a broad background in East Asian culture as a whole, while allowing the student to focus on a geographical or temporal aspect of East Asia. The minor may be designed from the following, for a total of six courses and a minimum of 20 units. All courses should be taken for a letter grade." />

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Minor in East Asian Studies </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-381" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/minor-requirement/minor-east-asian-studies" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Minor in East Asian Studies" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>The goal of the minor in East Asian Studies is to provide the student with a broad background in East Asian culture as a whole, while allowing the student to focus on a geographical or temporal aspect of East Asia. The minor may be designed from the following, for a total of six courses and a minimum of 20 units. All courses should be taken for a letter grade.</p>
<h2>East Asian Studies Minor Requirements</h2>
<ol><li>Three area courses, one in each category (see East Asian Studies List of Area Courses, see below).</li>
	<li>One undergraduate seminar above the 100 level and two other courses from among those listed as approved for East Asian Studies majors, including literature courses but excluding language courses. These courses are listed under the East Asian Studies major in this bulletin.</li>
</ol><p>Applications for the minor should be submitted online through Axess and are due no later than the second quarter of the junior year.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>East Asian Studies List of Area Courses</strong></p>
<p><strong>Humanities</strong></p>
<ul><li>CHINGEN 132, Chinese Fiction and Drama in Translation</li>
	<li>CHINGEN 133, Literature in 20th Century China</li>
	<li>CHINGEN 135, Chinese Bodies, Chinese Selves</li>
	<li>CHINGEN 194, The History and Culture of Peking Opera</li>
	<li>CHINGEN 198, Senior Colloquium in Chinese Studies</li>
	<li>JAPANGEN 124, Manga as Literature</li>
	<li>JAPANGEN 138, Introduction to Modern Japanese Literature and Culture</li>
	<li>JAPANGEN 184, Aristocrats, Warriors, Sex Workers, and Barbarians: Lived Life in Early Modern Japanese Painting</li>
	<li>KORGEN 101N, Kangnam Style: Korean Media and Pop Culture</li>
	<li>KORGEN 121, Doing the Right Thing: Ethical Dilemmas in Korean Film</li>
	<li>RELIGST 50, Exploring Buddhism</li>
	<li>RELIGST 55. Exploring Zen</li>
	<li>RELIGST 56, Exploring Chinese Religions</li>
</ul><p><strong>History</strong></p>
<ul><li>HISTORY 92. Early Empires in China </li>
	<li>HISTORY 11SC, How is a Buddhist </li>
	<li>HISTORY 13, The Historical and Geographical Background of Current Global Events </li>
	<li>HISTORY 92A, The Historical Roots of Modern East Asia </li>
	<li>HISTORY 95/195, Modern Korean History </li>
	<li>HISTORY 95C/195C, Modern Japanese History: From Samurai to Pokemon </li>
	<li>HISTORY 106A, Global Human Geography: Asia and Africa </li>
	<li>HISTORY 194B, Japan in the Age of the Samurai </li>
	<li>HISTORY 292F, Culture and Religions in Korean History </li>
	<li>HISTORY 295J, Chinese Women's History</li>
</ul><p><strong>Social Sciences </strong></p>
<ul><li>JAPANGEN 51, Japanese Business Culture and Systems </li>
	<li>EASTASN 217, Health and Healthcare Systems in East Asia </li>
	<li>LAW 245, China Law and Business </li>
	<li>IPS 244, U.S. Policy toward Northeast Asia </li>
	<li>IPS 246, China on the World Stage </li>
	<li>POLISCI 148, Chinese Politics: The Transformation and the Era of Reform </li>
	<li>POLISCI 211, Political Economy of East Asia </li>
	<li>SOC 116, Chinese Organizations and Management </li>
	<li>SOC 117A, China Under Mao </li>
	<li>SOC 167A, Asia-Pacific Transformation</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->

<meta name="description" content="As of September 1, 2016, the Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures will no longer offer the undergraduate minor in Chinese. In its place the department instead offers the minor in East Asian Studies, China Subplan. The &quot;China Subplan&quot; minor has been designed to give students majoring in other departments an opportunity to gain a substantial introduction to the Chinese language, as well as an introduction to the culture and civilization of East Asia." />

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Minor in East Asian Studies, China Subplan </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-437" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-east-asian-studies-china-subplan" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Minor in East Asian Studies, China Subplan" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary"><span>As of September 1, 2016, the Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures will no longer offer the undergraduate minor in Chinese. In its place the department instead offers the minor in East Asian Studies, China Subplan. The "China Subplan" minor has been designed to give students majoring in other departments an opportunity to gain a substantial introduction to the Chinese language, as well as an introduction to the culture and civilization of East Asia. Students who have delcared the Chinese minor prior to September 1, 2016 should still complete the Chinese minor requirements. Which can be found </span><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-chinese">here</a><span>.</span></p>
<h2>Minor in East Asian Studies, China Subplan</h2>
<p><span>The minors consist of a minimum of 20 units from the following requirements (see below). </span><span>All courses for the minor must be taken for a letter grade and completed with a GPA of 2.0 or better. Consult with the department to potentially count one of the BOSP courses taught by a Stanford home campus faculty member toward the minor</span><span>:</span></p>
<ol><li><strong>Proficiency of the modern Chinese language, at the second year level:</strong> Students study two years of modern Chinese. Students who already have a competence at the second-year level may fulfill the language component of the minor by taking three courses in the department using materials in Chinese. These courses may be language courses such as the third-year sequence mentioned above, the fourth-year language sequence, or they may be advanced literature and linguistics courses, depending on the capabilities and interests of the student.</li>
	<li><strong>Gateway courses:</strong> Complete two gateway courses offered by the EALC department; students make take courses from the “East Asian Gateway Course Cluster” and/or the “Gateway Course Cluster for China Subplan." At least one of the two gateway courses chosen must be taught by a member in the EALC department. <a href="https://stanford.box.com/v/EALCGatewayCourses" rel="nofollow">List of Approved Gateway Courses.</a></li>
	<li><strong>Additional content courses:</strong>Three courses selected from among the department's other offerings in the literature, linguistics, and civilization of the relevant minor area.</li>
</ol><p><span>​</span><span>For questions or inquiries regarding the minor, please contact our department student services officer, Ai Tran (</span><a href="mailto:aitran@stanford.edu?subject=Chinese%20Major%20Requirements" rel="nofollow">aitran@stanford.edu</a><span>).</span></p>
<p> </p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->

<div id="block-bean-jumpstart-footer-social-media-0" class="clearfix block block-bean span2">     <h2>Connect</h2>

<meta name="description" content="As of September 1, 2016, the Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures will no longer offer the undergraduate minor in Japanese. In its place the department instead offers the minor in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan. The &quot;Japan Subplan&quot; minor has been designed to give students majoring in other departments an opportunity to gain a substantial introduction to the Japanese language, as well as an introduction to the culture and civilization of East Asia." />

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Minor in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-438" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-east-asian-studies-japan-subplan" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Minor in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary"><span>As of September 1, 2016, the Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures will no longer offer the undergraduate minor in Japanese. In its place the department instead offers the minor in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan. The "Japan Subplan" minor has been designed to give students majoring in other departments an opportunity to gain a substantial introduction to the Japanese language, as well as an introduction to the culture and civilization of East Asia. Students who have delcared the Japanese minor prior to September 1, 2016 should still complete the Japanese minor requirements. Which can be found </span><a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-japanese">here</a><span>.</span></p>
<div>
	<h2>Minor in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan</h2>
	<p>The minors consist of a minimum of 20 units from the following requirements (see below). All courses for the minor must be taken for a letter grade and completed with a GPA of 2.0 or better. Consult with the department to potentially count one of the BOSP courses taught by a Stanford home campus faculty member toward the minor:</p>
	<ol><li><span>Proficiency of the modern Japanese language, at the second year level:</span> Students study two years of modern Japanese. Students who already have a competence at the second-year level may fulfill the language component of the minor by taking three courses in the department using materials in Japanese. These courses may be language courses such as the third-year sequence mentioned above, the fourth-year language sequence, or they may be advanced literature and linguistics courses, depending on the capabilities and interests of the student.</li>
		<li><span>Gateway courses:</span> Complete two gateway courses offered by the EALC department; students make take courses from the “East Asian Gateway Course Cluster” and/or the “Gateway Course Cluster for Japan Subplan." At least one of the two gateway courses chosen must be taught by a member in the EALC department. <a href="https://stanford.box.com/v/EALCGatewayCourses" rel="nofollow">List of Approved Gateway Courses.</a></li>
		<li><span>Additional content courses:</span>Three courses selected from among the department's other offerings in the literature, linguistics, and civilization of the relevant minor area.</li>
	</ol><p>​For questions or inquiries regarding the minor, please contact our department student services officer, Ai Tran (<a href="mailto:aitran@stanford.edu?subject=Chinese%20Major%20Requirements" rel="nofollow">aitran@stanford.edu</a>).</p>
</div>
<p> </p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->

The &quot;Korea Subplan&quot; minor has been designed to give students majoring in other departments an opportunity to gain a substantial introduction to the Korean language, as well as an introduction to the culture and civilization of East Asia." />

Email: csquare@stanford.edu">Giving</a></li>

  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Undergraduate Program</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-stanford_jsa_layouts-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">
  <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-993"><a href="/undergraduate-program/undergraduate-program-overview">Overview</a></li>

<li class="expanded active-trail menu-mlid-969 dropdown-submenu"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor-requirements" class="active-trail dropdown-toggle" data-toggle="dropdown" data-target="#">Minor Requirements</a><ul class="dropdown-menu"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-986"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-chinese">Minor in Chinese</a></li>

<li class="leaf active-trail active menu-mlid-1187"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor-requirements/minor-east-asian-studies-korea-subplan" class="active-trail active">Minor in East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan</a></li>

        <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Minor in East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-439" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/minor-requirements/minor-east-asian-studies-korea-subplan" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Minor in East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary">As of September 1, 2016, the Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures will offer a new undergraduate program: the minor in East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan. The "Korea Subplan" minor has been designed to give students majoring in other departments an opportunity to gain a substantial introduction to the Korean language, as well as an introduction to the culture and civilization of East Asia.</p>
<div>
	<h2>Minor in East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan</h2>
	<p>The minors consist of a minimum of 20 units from the following requirements (see below). All courses for the minor must be taken for a letter grade and completed with a GPA of 2.0 or better. Consult with the department to potentially count one of the BOSP courses taught by a Stanford home campus faculty member toward the minor:</p>
	<ol><li><strong>Proficiency of the modern Korean language, at the second year level: </strong>Students complete two years of modern Korean. Those who already have a competence at the second-year level may fulfill the language component of the minor by taking three courses in the department using materials in Korean. These courses may be language courses such as the third-year sequence mentioned above, the fourth-year language sequence, or they may be advanced literature and linguistics courses, depending on the capabilities and interests of the student.</li>
		<li><strong>Gateway courses:</strong> Complete two gateway courses offered by the EALC department; students make take courses from the “East Asian Gateway Course Cluster” and/or the “Gateway Course Cluster for Korea Subplan." At least one of the two gateway courses chosen must be taught by a member in the EALC department. <a href="https://stanford.box.com/v/EALCGatewayCourses" rel="nofollow">List of Approved Gateway Courses.</a></li>
		<li><strong>Additional content courses:</strong>Three courses selected from among the department's other offerings in the literature, film, and popular culture. Up to one course can be approved from outside the department with the Director of Undergraduate Studies's approval.</li>
	</ol><p>​For questions or inquiries regarding the minor, please contact our department student services officer, Ai Tran (<a href="mailto:aitran@stanford.edu?subject=Chinese%20Major%20Requirements" rel="nofollow">aitran@stanford.edu</a>).</p>
</div>
<p> </p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->

<meta name="description" content="The undergraduate minors in Chinese and Japanese have been designed to give students majoring in other departments an opportunity to gain a substantial introduction to Chinese or Japanese language, as well as an introduction to the culture and civilization of East Asia. The minors consist of a minimum of 20 units from the following requirements: One introductory core course, below. Three other departmental courses in the relevant field approved by the adviser, and language requirement as listed below." />

  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Undergraduate Program</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-stanford_jsa_layouts-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">
  <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-993"><a href="/undergraduate-program/undergraduate-program-overview">Overview</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-968"><a href="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements">Major Requirements</a></li>
<li class="expanded active-trail menu-mlid-969 dropdown-submenu"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor-requirements" class="active-trail dropdown-toggle" data-toggle="dropdown" data-target="#">Minor Requirements</a><ul class="dropdown-menu"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-986"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-chinese">Minor in Chinese</a></li>
<li class="leaf active-trail active menu-mlid-987"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-japanese" class="active-trail active">Minor in Japanese</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1179"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor-requirement/minor-east-asian-studies">Minor in East Asian Studies</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1185"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-east-asian-studies-china-subplan">Minor in East Asian Studies, China Subplan</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1186"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-east-asian-studies-japan-subplan">Minor in East Asian Studies, Japan Subplan</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1187"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor-requirements/minor-east-asian-studies-korea-subplan">Minor in East Asian Studies, Korea Subplan</a></li>
<li class="last leaf menu-mlid-1188"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-translation-studies">Minor in Translation Studies</a></li>
</ul></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-612"><a href="/undergraduate-program/honors-program-application-requirements">Honors Program - Applications and Requirements</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-971"><a href="/undergraduate-program/research-opportunities">Research Opportunities</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-972"><a href="/undergraduate-program/study-abroad">Study Abroad</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-973"><a href="/undergraduate-program/undergraduate-awards">Undergraduate Awards</a></li>

</ul></div>

</div>
</div>
 <!-- /.region -->
</div>
        </div>
        <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Minor in Japanese </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-147" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-japanese" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Minor in Japanese" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>The undergraduate minors in Chinese and Japanese have been designed to give students majoring in other departments an opportunity to gain a substantial introduction to Chinese or Japanese language, as well as an introduction to the culture and civilization of East Asia. The minors consist of a minimum of 20 units from the following requirements: One introductory core course, below. Three other departmental courses in the relevant field approved by the adviser, and language requirement as listed below.</p>
<h2>Japanese Minor Requirements</h2>
<ol><li>Completion of language study through the second-year level for students with no previous training in Japanese. Students who already have first-year competence in Japanese must complete the third-year course. Students who already have a competence at the second-year level may fulfill the language component of the minor by taking three courses in the department using materials in either Chinese or Japanese. These courses may be language courses such as the third-year sequence mentioned above, the fourth-year language sequence, or they may be advanced literature and linguistics courses, depending on the capabilities and interests of the student.</li>
	<li>JAPANGEN 92: Introduction to Japan</li>
	<li>Three courses selected from among the department's other offerings in the literature, linguistics, and civilization of the relevant minor area (JAPANGEN, JAPANLIT). All courses for the minor must be taken for a letter grade and completed with a GPA of 2.0 or better. Consult with the Undergraduate Studies Adviser to potentially count one of the OSPKYOTO courses taught by a Stanford home campus faculty member toward the minor.</li>
</ol></div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>
                                                                                                                      </div>

        </div>

<meta name="description" content="The Division of Literatures, Cultures, and Languages (DLCL), in cooperation with East Asian Languages and Cultures (EALC) and the English Department, teaches undergraduates to develop and apply their foreign language knowledge to the production and analysis of translations. The minor is designed to give students majoring in a variety of fields the tools to consider the practical and theoretical issues brought up by translation as an aesthetic, cultural, and ethical practice." />

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Minor in Translation Studies </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-440" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/minor/minor-translation-studies" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Minor in Translation Studies" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary"><span>The Division of Literatures, Cultures, and Languages (DLCL), in cooperation with East Asian Languages and Cultures (EALC) and the English Department, teaches undergraduates to develop and apply their foreign language knowledge to the production and analysis of translations. The minor is designed to give students majoring in a variety of fields the tools to consider the practical and theoretical issues brought up by translation as an aesthetic, cultural, and ethical practice.</span></p>
<h2>Minor in Translation Studies</h2>
<p><em>Minor Adviser: <a href="mailto:csantana@stanford.edu?subject=Minor%20in%20Translation%20Studies" rel="nofollow">Cintia Santana</a></em></p>
<p><em>Faculty Director: <a href="mailto:ilevy@stanford.edu?subject=Minor%20in%20Translation%20Studies" rel="nofollow">Indra Levy</a></em></p>
<p>The DLCL offers a "Minor in Translation Studies" which may be of interest to students in EALC. See the DLCL's "<a href="http://exploredegrees.stanford.edu/schoolofhumanitiesandsciences/divisionofliteraturesculturesandlanguages/#minortext">Minors</a>" tab for the full requirements; go to the menu in the right hand column and click on the link to the "Minor in Translation Studies". Course work in this minor may not duplicate work counted toward other majors or minors. Course selection must be approved by the minor adviser.</p>
<p>Students must take a minimum of 23 units for a letter grade, in fulfillment of the following requirements:</p>
<ol><li><strong>Prerequisite: </strong>Complete or test out of a first-year course in the language of interest.</li>
	<li><strong>Core course: </strong>At least 4 units in a Translation Studies core course: ENGLISH/DLCL 293, COMPLIT 142B/JAPAN 121 or JAPAN 122/KOREA 122</li>
	<li><strong>Language study: </strong>At least 8 units, second year or beyond (not including conversation/oral communication) and/or relevant literature courses taught in the target language. OSP and transfer units may be considered in consultation with the minor adviser.</li>
	<li><strong>Literature study: </strong>At least 7 units in relevant literature courses at the 100-level or above, taught in a DLCL department, East Asian Languages and Cultures, or Classics, and determined in consultation with the minor adviser. For students interested in translation from English into another language, appropriate literature courses in the English department may be substituted.</li>
	<li><strong>Electives:</strong> At least 4 units in a creative writing course, or a course that foregrounds translation in departments such as Anthropology, any DLCL department, English, East Asian Languages and Cultures, Classics, Linguistics (e.g., LINGUIST 130A), or Computer Science (e.g., CS 124), determined in consultation with the minor adviser.</li>
	<li><strong>Final Project: </strong>Students must also complete a capstone project: a significant translation and/or translation studies project (e.g. 20 pages of prose, 10 poems, or similar appropriate amount to be determined in consultation with the minor adviser). This work may be carried out under the supervision of an instructor in a required course or as an independent study.</li>
</ol></div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

  <div id="block-menu-menu-footer-about-menu" class="clearfix block block-menu span2">     <h2>About</h2>

<div id="block-menu-menu-footer-academics-menu" class="clearfix block block-menu span2">     <h2>Academics</h2>
      <div class="content"> <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf"><a href="/undergraduate-program/undergraduate-program-overview" title="">Undergraduate Program</a></li>

<div id="block-menu-menu-footer-people-menu" class="clearfix block block-menu span2">     <h2>People</h2>
      <div class="content"> <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf"><a href="/people/faculty">Faculty</a></li>
<li class="leaf"><a href="/people/lecturers" title="">Lecturers</a></li>
<li class="leaf"><a href="/people/emeriti-faculty" title="">Emeriti Faculty</a></li>
<li class="leaf"><a href="/people/graduate-students" title="">Graduate Students</a></li>

  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Undergraduate Program</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-stanford_jsa_layouts-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Prospective Undergrads </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-123" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/prospective-undergrads" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Prospective Undergrads" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>Students interested in majoring or minoring Chinese, Japanese, or East Asian Studies should contact our Department's Student Services Officer (<a href="mailto:aitran@stanford.edu" rel="nofollow">aitran@stanford.edu</a>) to schedule a meeting. During the meeting, students will go over departmental requirements to make sure that he or she understands program requirements before declaring the major or minor on Axess/Peoplesoft.</p>
<p>Please note that the major/minor requirements may change from year-to-year, so students should check the bulletin archive to make sure that he or she completes the major requirements from the year that he or she has declared the major. Once the major/minor declaration is approved, students will be added onto our department mailing list to be notified of upcoming department events/opportunities relevant undergraduates in our department. Students' names and program(s) of study will also be added to our department website, under the <a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/people/undergraduate-students">Undergraduates</a> section. </p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

            <div id="main-content" class="row main-content">
                <div id="sidebar-first" class="sidebar site-sidebar-first span3">
          <div class="row-fluid"><div class="region region-sidebar-first clearfix">
  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Undergraduate Program</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-stanford_jsa_layouts-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">
  <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-993"><a href="/undergraduate-program/undergraduate-program-overview">Overview</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-968"><a href="/undergraduate-program/major-requirements">Major Requirements</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-969"><a href="/undergraduate-program/minor-requirements">Minor Requirements</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-612"><a href="/undergraduate-program/honors-program-application-requirements">Honors Program - Applications and Requirements</a></li>
<li class="leaf active-trail active menu-mlid-971"><a href="/undergraduate-program/research-opportunities" class="active-trail active">Research Opportunities</a></li>

<li class="last leaf menu-mlid-975"><a href="/undergraduate-program/prospective-undergrads">Prospective Undergrads</a></li>
