 <!-- /.region -->
</div>
        </div>
        <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Research Opportunities </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-119" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/research-opportunities" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Research Opportunities" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>East Asian Languages and Cultures supports our students' interest in studying East Asia. Students interested in research may consider independent study or pursuing the honors program as part of their major. They may also choose to seek for funding sources outside of the department and ask EALC faculty members to serve as their adviser for their research projects. We have listed some resources that we recommend:</p>
<ul><li><a href="https://undergrad.stanford.edu/opportunities/research/get-funded/apply-uar-student-grants">Supplementary Grants for Undergraduate Field Work in East Asia through Undergraduate Research and Adivsing (UAR):</a> Undergraduate Advising and Research (UAR) Student Grants support rigorous, independent projects in all disciplines. Research, arts, and senior synthesis projects in any field (including engineering, fine arts, humanities, natural sciences, and social sciences) can make use of this funding. All Student Grants are subject to the same policies and processes. <strong>These grants are based on a rolling deadline and available to all currently-enrolled Stanford undergraduates.</strong></li>
	<li><a href="https://sgs.stanford.edu/programs-centers/global-studies-internship-program">Stanford Global Studies Internship Program: </a>The Global Studies Internship Program collaborates with international area studies programs and centers within SGS. Currently enrolled freshmen, sophomores, juniors, seniors, and coterms at Stanford in ALL majors are eligible to apply, including students who are undeclared. <strong>For the 20115-16 academic year, the deadline is February 9, 2016, and eligible to all currently-enrolled Stanford undergraduates.</strong></li>
	<li><a href="https://solo.stanford.edu/content/ceas-undergraduate-overseas-summer-language-study-fellowships">Undergraduate Overseas Summer Language Study Fellowships: </a>Undergraduate Overseas Summer Language Study Fellowships provide partial funding to support Stanford undergraduates who study Chinese, Japanese, or Korean (or other approved languages by petition) in a full-time, pre-approved, accredited overseas summer language program. Applicants must have completed at least first-year language courses before the fellowship commences. Preference will be given to East Asian Studies majors and minors and to students who have taken two or more East Asian Studies content courses. <strong>For the 20115-16 academic year, the deadline is February 19, 2016, and eligible to all currently-enrolled Stanford undergraduates.</strong></li>
	<li><a href="https://solo.stanford.edu/content/ceas-undergraduate-academic-year-east-asia-flas-fellowships">Undergraduate Academic-Year East Asia FLAS Fellowships:</a> Department of Education Foreign Language and Area Studies (FLAS) Fellowships provide $10,000 in tuition and $5,000 stipend for undergraduate students in any discipline for intensive language study at Stanford during the academic year—at the intermediate (2nd year) or advanced (3rd year+) level—in conjunction with international or area studies courses. Students must enroll in both advanced Chinese, Japanese, or Korean (or other approved languages by petition) and area-studies courses simultaneously during the entire period of award. Applicants must be a U.S. citizen or permanent resident and must be deemed eligible by the University for at least $15,000 in financial aid to receive the award. Grants subject to final approval from the Department of Education. <strong>For the 20115-16 academic year, the deadline is May 19, 2016, and eligible to all currently-enrolled Stanford undergraduates who are U.S. citizens and permanent residents.</strong></li>
</ul><p>As we discover more funding resources and research opportunities for our undergraduates, we will post them on this website, so please check back occasionally. You may also contact our Student Services Officer (<a href="mailto:aitran@stanford.edu" rel="nofollow">aitran@stanford.edu</a>) for more information.</p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>

  <!-- Set the viewport width to device width for mobile -->

            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Study Abroad </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-120" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/study-abroad" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Study Abroad" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-image group_s_postcard_image"><div class="field-collection-container clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-info field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-large-scaled field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/298" typeof="">
  <div class="content">
    <div class="border-simple-nowidth border-shadow"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/large-scaled/public/2014-07-13_19.32.22.jpg?itok=a4J-4wCs" width="270" height="203" alt="" /></div></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p class="summary"><span>Thinking about studying away from Stanford?</span></p>
<p>The <a href="https://undergrad.stanford.edu/programs/bosp/explore/study-abroad-overview">Bing Overseas Study Program (BOSP)</a> offers quarters abroad in twelve cities around the world, including summer options in Oaxaca, Cape Town, and Santiago, as well as shorter Overseas Seminars. In addition, you can do a quarter in Monterey with Hopkins Marine Station, Stanford-at-Sea (half in Monterey, half on a sailing ship in the South Pacific), a quarter in Hawaii with Earth Systems, or Stanford-in-Washington (policy-themed, plus a new arts-themed option in winter), or Stanford-in-NYC (launched Fall 2015 with an arts theme). EALC majors and minors studying at the Bing Overseas Program in Kyoto or Beijing may receive partial credit towards their undergraduate program requirements. For more details, please contact the Student Services Officer (aitran@stanford.edu)</p>
<h3><a href="https://undergrad.stanford.edu/programs/bosp/explore/beijing/about-beijing-program">Bing Overseas Studies Program: Beijing</a></h3>
<p>Stanford’s Beijing Program, opened in Autumn of 2004, is hosted by the prestigious Peking University (PKU), which is located just outside the heart of China’s bustling capital city. Open during Autumn and Spring quarters only, students are exposed to the rich culture of this paradoxically ancient and modern city through coursework and field trips. Courses are taught primarily in English. In Autumn 2016, Professor Yiqun Zhou will be teaching two courses at the BOSP: Beijing campus. <a href="https://undergrad.stanford.edu/programs/bosp/explore/beijing/about-beijing-program">For more information on the Beijing program, please visit BOSP: Beijing.</a></p>
<h3><a href="https://undergrad.stanford.edu/programs/bosp/explore/kyoto/about-kyoto-program">Bing Overseas Studies Program: Kyoto</a></h3>
<p>With its history as Japan’s former Imperial capital for over a millennium, Kyoto is rightly famed for its ancient shrines and temples (which outnumber its convenience stores), its traditional ryokan inns and its centuries-old craftsmanship. Even today the city retains its status as the cultural capital of the nation. Despite its old-world feel Kyoto is an energetic city looking firmly to the future, with an impressive list of high tech companies making their home here. The Stanford in Kyoto center is situated inside Doshisha University, on the northern edge of the old Imperial Palace gardens in the heart of the city. Students can take Winter and/or Spring Quarter academic programs, as well as an optional 10-week summer internship at leading companies and institutions all over Japan. The curriculum typically combines intensive Japanese language study with Japan-focused content courses on culture, contemporary affairs, business and technology. <a href="https://undergrad.stanford.edu/programs/bosp/explore/kyoto/about-kyoto-program">For more information on the Beijing program, please visit BOSP: Kyoto</a></p>
<h3>Non-Stanford Overseas Studies Program</h3>
<p>Undergraduates who have studied or plan on studying abroad through a non-Stanford overseas program should consult with the Student Services Officer (aitran@stanford.edu) on whether or not he or she may be eligible to receive partial credit through that undergraduate program. In the past, we have allowed partial credit for students who have studied at the Inter-University Center (IUC) for Japanese Language Studies and the Inter-University Program (IUP) for Chinese Language Studies.</p>
<h2>Tips for Advanced Planning:</h2>
<ul><li>Explore the BOSP Beijing and Kyoto webpages to get the basics. Pay attention to what quarter programs are offered, and whether a particular quarter has a certain theme.</li>
	<li>Attend an info session on Study Abroad or about a particular program.</li>
	<li>See what classes each option offers (BOSP publishes classes over a year in advance).</li>
	<li>Identify language requirements or other prerequisites for your preferred program(s) and work out a plan to meet and go beyond the prerequisites. The better your language skills, the more you will get out of being abroad (and the more competitive your application will be).</li>
	<li>Talk to people who’ve gone on the program--BOSP and several other programs list official Peer Advisors who are available.</li>
	<li>Develop your background knowledge. This might mean: taking related classes; picking related topics for a free-choice research paper; related internships or service. (Discussing such items can strengthen an application.)</li>
	<li>Talk to faculty associated with the program.</li>
	<li>Apply! Remember to check the application deadlines - usually they are at least two quarters in advance, sometimes more.</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->

<meta name="description" content="James J. Y. Liu Prize for Distinguished Undergraduate Work in Asian Languages and Culture One prize is offered by the Asian Languages Department to an outstanding undergraduate who has written an outstanding essay for an EALC class on the literature or culture of China, Japan, and/or Korean in English and recommended by a teacher. The length of the essay is of secondary concern, but it should represent a substantial effort vis-à-vis the topic." />

          <div class="row-fluid"><div class="region region-sidebar-first clearfix">
  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Undergraduate Program</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-stanford_jsa_layouts-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">
  <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-993"><a href="/undergraduate-program/undergraduate-program-overview">Overview</a></li>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title">  Undergraduate Awards </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-121" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/undergraduate-awards" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content=" Undergraduate Awards" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><h2>James J. Y. Liu Prize for Distinguished Undergraduate Work in Asian Languages and Culture</h2>
<p>One prize is offered by the Asian Languages Department to an outstanding undergraduate who has written an outstanding essay for an EALC class on the literature or culture of China, Japan, and/or Korean in English and recommended by a teacher. The length of the essay is of secondary concern, but it should represent a substantial effort vis-à-vis the topic.</p>
<h2>Kung-Yi Kao Prize for Outstanding Progress in the Study of Chinese, Japanese, or Korean Language</h2>
<p>One prize is offered by the Asian Languages Department to an outstanding undergraduate in a third or fourth year language course in the department. A major criterion in judging candidates for this prize will be overall progress in the language in question.</p>
<br /><p><strong>Note: </strong>The undergraduate awards will be announced at the Diploma Ceremony for the Center of East Asian Studies and Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures. Award winners will be notified after the Ceremony.</p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

<div id="block-bean-jumpstart-footer-contact-block" class="clearfix block block-bean span2">     <h2>Contact Us</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="entity entity-bean bean-stanford-contact clearfix" about="/block/jumpstart-footer-contact-block" typeof="">

        <div id="top-logo" class="span4"><a href="http://www.stanford.edu"><img src="/sites/all/themes/stanford_framework/images/header-stanford-logo@2x.png" alt="Stanford University"></a></div>

<div id="block-bean-jumpstart-undergraduate-in-the-s" class="clearfix block block-bean well">     <h2>Why study Asia?</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="entity entity-bean bean-stanford-postcard clearfix" about="/block/jumpstart-undergraduate-in-the-s" typeof="">

  <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard"><div class="field-collection-container clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-info field-type-field-collection field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-4-col-header field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/258" typeof="">
  <div class="content">
    <div class="border-simple-nowidth border-shadow"><div class="field field-name-field-s-image-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://files-ealc-stanford-edu.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/styles/4-col-header/public/2013-07-07_18.12.15.jpg?itok=9gZMREKV" width="370" height="140" alt="" /></div></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-field-s-postcard-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span>“I graduated from Stanford with a degree in Japanese ... I left to teach high school in Japan for a couple of years. It was a great experience: I solidified my language skills, gained some perspective on employment and life in Japan, and made lifelong friends. The linguistic and cultural understanding I gained at Stanford (and during my time in Japan) continues to enrich my life on a daily basis.”</span></p>
<p><span>-- Mike Massey '[year?]</span></p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
 </div>
</div>
</div>
 <!-- /.region -->
</div>
        </div>
        <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Undergraduate Program Overview </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-151" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/undergraduate-program-overview" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Undergraduate Program Overview" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><h2>Bachelor of Arts Degrees</h2>
<p>The Department of East Asian Languages and Cultures Bachelor of Arts degrees in:</p>
<ul><li>Chinese</li>
	<li>Japanese</li>
	<li>East Asian Studies</li>
</ul><p>Required courses and pre-requisites must be completed with a grade point average (GPA) of 2.0 or better.</p>
<h2>Bachelor of Arts Degrees, Honors Programs</h2>
<p>Students majoring in Chinese, Japanese, or East Asian Studies with an overall GPA of 3.5 or higher may apply for the honors program honors program by submitting a senior thesis proposal to the honors committee during Winter or Spring Quarter of the junior year. If approved, research begins the Spring Quarter of the junior year, or by Autumn Quarter of the senior year at the latest. In Winter Quarter of the senior year, students enroll in independent study with the thesis supervisor while writing the thesis, and the finished essay (normally about 15,000 words) is submitted to the committee no later than April 15 of the senior year. For more information, <a href="https://ealc.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/honors-program">please review the Honors Program requirements.</a></p>
<h2>Bachelor of Arts Degrees, Minor Programs</h2>
<p>The minor in Asian Languages (Chinese, Japanese or East Asian Studies) is also available. These have been designed to give students majoring in other departments an opportunity to gain substantial introduction to Chinese (Mandarin) or Japanese language, as well as an introduction to the culture and civilization of East Asia.</p>
</div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>
